page.title: International Code of Nomenclature of Prokaryotes

revision.text:
The '''International Code of Nomenclature of Prokaryotes (ICNP)''' formerly the '''International Code of Nomenclature of Bacteria''' ('''ICNB''') or '''Bacteriological Code''' ('''BC''') governs the [[scientific name]]s for [[Bacteria]] and [[Archaea]].<ref>[http://www.the-icsp.org International Committee on Systematics of Prokaryotes (ICSP)]</ref><ref name=Sneath>P. H. A. Sneath, 2003. A short history of the Bacteriological Code [http://www.the-icsp.org/misc/Code_history.htm URL] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120524070542/http://www.the-icsp.org/misc/Code_history.htm |date=2012-05-24 }}</ref> It denotes the rules for naming [[taxon|taxa]] of bacteria, according to their relative rank. As such it is one of the [[Nomenclature Codes|nomenclature codes]] of [[biology]].
Originally the ''[[International Code of Botanical Nomenclature]]'' dealt with bacteria, and this kept references to bacteria until these were eliminated at the 1975 [[International Botanical Congress|IBC]]. An early Code for the nomenclature of bacteria was approved at the 4th International Congress for Microbiology in 1947, but was later discarded.
The latest version to be printed in book form is the 1990 Revision,<ref>[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/bv.fcgi?rid=icnb.section.185 ''Bacteriological Code (1990 Revision)'']</ref> but the book does not represent the current rules, as the Code has been amended since (these changes have been published in the ''[[International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology]]'' (''IJSEM'')).<ref name=Sneath/> The rules are maintained by the [[International Committee on Systematics of Prokaryotes]] (ICSP; formerly the International Committee on Systematic Bacteriology, ICSB).
The base-line for bacterial names is the Approved Lists<ref>VBD Skerman, Vicki McGowan, and PHA Sneath, 1989. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/bookshelf/br.fcgi?book=bacname ''Approved Lists of Bacterial Names, Amended edition''] Washington (DC): [[ASM Press]]</ref> with a starting point of 1980. New bacterial names are reviewed by the ICSP as being in conformity with the Rules of Nomenclature and published in the ''IJSEM''.
As of 2011, the formal separation of the botanical and bacteriological codes continues to cause problems with the nomenclature of certain groups.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Oren, A.|year=2011|title=Cyanobacterial systematics and nomenclature as featured in the International Bulletin of Bacteriological Nomenclature and Taxonomy / International Journal of Systematic Bacteriology / International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology|journal=International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology|volume=61|issue=1|pages=10–15|url=http://ijs.sgmjournals.org/content/61/1/10.abstract|doi=10.1099/ijs.0.018838-0|pmid=21097637}}</ref>
==Versions== * Buchanan, R. E., and Ralph St. John-Brooks. (1947, June) (Editors). ''Proposed Bacteriological Code of Nomenclature''. Developed from proposals approved by International Committee on Bacteriological Nomenclature at the Meeting of the Third International Congress for Microbiology. Publication authorized in Plenary Session, pp. 61. Iowa State College Press, Ames, Iowa. U.S.A. [https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/009111230 Hathi Trust]. * Buchanan R. E., St. John-Brooks R., Breed R. S. (1948). International bacteriological code of nomenclature. ''Journal of Bacteriology'' 55:287–306. [http://jb.asm.org/content/55/3/287.long link]. Reprinted 1949, ''Journal of General Microbiology'' 3, 444–462. * International Committee on Bacteriological Nomenclature. (1958, June). ''International code of nomenclature of bacteria and viruses''. Ames, Iowa State College Press. [https://www.biodiversitylibrary.org/bibliography/6959#/summary BHL]. * Lapage, S.P., Sneath, P.H.A., Lessel, E.F., Skerman, V.B.D., Seeliger, H.P.R. & Clark, W.A. (1975). ''International Code of Nomenclature of Bacteria''. 1975 Revision. American Society of Microbiology, Washington, D.C * Lapage, S.P., Sneath, P.H.A., Lessel, E.F., Skerman, V.B.D., Seeliger, H.P.R. & Clark, W.A. (1992). ''International Code of Nomenclature of Bacteria''. Bacteriological Code. 1990 Revision. American Society for Microbiology, Washington, D.C. [https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK8817/ link]. * Parker, C.T., Tindall, B.J. & Garrity, G.M. (2015) ''International Code of Nomenclature of Prokaryotes.'' 2008 Revision. Microbiology Society doi: [http://doi.org/10.1099/ijsem.0.000778 10.1099/ijsem.0.000778] (published ahead of print)
== See also == * [[International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses]] * [[Society for General Microbiology]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://ijs.sgmjournals.org/ ''International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology Online''] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080803081454/http://www.bacterio.cict.fr/Tindall.html HTML Tindall, B.J. (1999). Misunderstanding the Bacteriological Code] Int J Syst Bacteriol. 49, 1313-1316. {{DOI|10.1099/00207713-49-3-1313}} {{PMID|10425796}}. (HTML) or [http://ijs.sgmjournals.org/cgi/reprint/49/3/1313.pdf PDF] * [http://www.bacterio.cict.fr List of Prokaryotic Names with Standing in Nomenclature]
[[Category:International standards]] [[Category:Bacterial nomenclature]]

'''Intra-industry trade''' refers to the exchange of similar products belonging to the same industry. The term is usually applied to [[international trade]], where the same types of goods or services are both imported and exported.
==Examples== Examples of this kind of trade include [[automobile]]s, foodstuffs and [[beverage]]s, computers and minerals.
Europe exported 2.6 million motor vehicles in 2002, and imported 2.2 million of them. Japan exported 4.7 million vehicles in 2002 (1 million of which went to Europe, and 2 million to North America), and imported 0.3 million.
==Explanation== Why do countries at the same time import and export the products of the same industry, or import and export the same kinds of goods?
According to Nigel Grimwade, "An explanation cannot be found within the framework of classical or neo-classical trade theory. The latter predicts only inter-industry specialisation and trade".<ref>{{Cite book |last=Grimwade |first=Nigel |title=International Trade: New Patterns of Trade, Production & Investment |edition=Second |year=2000 |location=New York |publisher=Routledge |page=71 |isbn=0-415-15626-2 }}</ref> However, this is far from the case.
The traditional model of trade were set out by the model of [[David Ricardo]] and the [[Heckscher–Ohlin model]], which tried to explain the occurrence of [[international trade]]. Both models used the idea of [[comparative advantage]] and an explanation of why countries trade. However, many economists have made the point of claiming that these models provide no explanation towards intra-industry trade as under their assumptions countries with identical factor endowments would not trade and produce goods domestically.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Krugman |first=Paul |last2=Obstfeld |first2=Maurice |year=1991 |title=International Economics: Theory and Policy |location=New York |publisher=Harper Collins |isbn=0-673-52151-6 |edition=Second }}</ref> Hence, as intra-industry trade has developed many economists have looked at other explanations.
One attempt to explain IIT was made by Finger (1975), who thought that occurrence of intra-industry trade was “unremarkable” as existing classifications place goods of heterogeneous factor endowments in a single industry. However, evidence shows that even when industries are disaggregated to extremely fine levels IIT still occurs, so this argument can be ignored.
Another potential explanation is provided by Flavey & Kierzkowski (1987). They produced a model that tried to get rid of the idea that all products are produced under identical technical conditions. Their model showed that on the [[demand|demand side]] goods are distinguished by the perceived quality of that good and high quality goods are produced under conditions of high capital intensity. However, this explanation has also been dismissed.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Brander |first=James A. |year=1987 |title=Book Review of Greenaway and Milner (1986) |journal=Journal of International Economics |volume=23 |issue=1/2 |pages=182–185 |doi=10.1016/S0022-1996(87)80013-2 }}</ref> It is questioned whether the model applies to IIT at all, as it does not address directly trade between goods of ''similar'' factor endowments.
The most comprehensive and widely accepted explanation, at least within economic theory, is that of [[Paul Krugman]]'s [[New Trade Theory]]. Krugman argues that economies specialise to take advantage of increasing returns, not following differences in regional endowments (as contended by [[Neoclassical economics|neoclassical]] theory). In particular, trade allows countries to specialise in a limited variety of production and thus reap the advantages of increasing returns (i.e., [[economies of scale]]), but without reducing the variety of goods available for consumption.
Yet, [[Donald Davis (economist)|Donald Davis]] believed that both the Heckscher–Ohlin and Ricardian models were still relevant in explaining intra-industry trade.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Davis |first=D. R. |year=1995 |title=Intra-industry trade: A Heckscher-Ohlin-Ricardo approach |journal=Journal of International Economics |volume=39 |issue=3/4 |pages=201–226 |doi=10.1016/0022-1996(95)01383-3 }}</ref> He developed the Heckscher-Ohlin-Ricardo model, which showed that even with constant returns to scale that intra-industry trade could still occur under the traditional setting. The Heckscher-Ohlin-Ricardo model explained that countries of identical factor endowments would still trade due to differences in technology, as this would encourage specialisation and therefore trade, in exactly the same matter that was set out in the Ricardian model.
;Types There are three types of intra-industry trade #Trade in Homogeneous Goods. #Trade in Horizontally Differentiated Goods. #Trade in Vertically Differentiated Goods.
Although the theory and measurement of intra-industry trade initially focused on trade in goods, especially industrial products, it has also been observed that there is substantial intra-industry trade in the international trade of services.<ref>Shelburne, Robert C. ; Gonzales, Jorge (2004). "The Role of Intra-Industry Trade in the Service Sector", in Michael Plummer (ed.) ''Empirical Methods in International Trade: Essays in Honor of Mordechai Kreinin'', Edward Elgar Press, 110-128, 2004.</ref>
==Measurement== Intra-industry trade is difficult to measure statistically because regarding products or industries as "the same" is partly a matter of definition and classification.
For a very simple example, it could be argued that although a [[BMW]] and a [[Ford Motor Company|Ford]] are both motor cars, and although a [[Budweiser (Anheuser-Busch)|Budweiser]] and a [[Heineken]] are both beers, they are really all different products.
Various indexes of IIT have been created, including the [[Grubel–Lloyd index]], the [[Balassa index]], the [[Aquino index]], the [[Bergstrand index]] and the [[Glesjer index]]. Research suggests that
*IIT is not simply a fiction or artifact produced by statistical classifications and definitions, but very much a reality. *the share of IIT in total international trade is growing all the time, at about 4–5% a year. Thus, more and more, countries are importing the same kinds of products they are also exporting.
"Intra-industry trade has been considered in international trade literature as the explanation of the unexpectedly large expansion of industrial trade among OECD countries, for which it represented more than two-thirds of their total international trade by the beginning of the seventies."<ref>{{Cite journal |first=Bela |last=Kadar |title=Review of Herbert Giersch, ''On the economics of intra-industry trade'' |journal=Journal of Economic Literature |volume=19 |issue=3 |year=1981 |pages=1109 |doi= }}</ref>
== See also == {{Portal|Economics}} *[[Inter-industry trade]] *[[Marginal intra-industry trade]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:International trade]]

revision.comment: [[Wikipedia:Bots/Requests for approval/PrimeBOT 29|Task 29]] - removal of deprecated parameters from [[Template:infobox person]] (+ genfixes)
revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = James Reed | image = [[File:James Reed.jpg]] | alt = | caption = | image_size = 220px | birth_name = James A. Reed | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=y|1963|04|12}} | birth_place = [[Woking]], Surrey, England | nationality = British and Maltese | occupation = Chairman and CEO, [[Reed (company)|Reed Group]] | website = https://www.reed.co.uk/james-reed/ | spouse = Nicola Reed née Arkell | children = 6 | parents = [[Sir Alec Reed]], Adrianne Reed (née Eyre) }} '''James A. Reed''' (born April 1963) is a British businessman, the [[Chairman#Public corporations|chairman]] and chief executive of the [[Reed (company)|Reed]] group of companies, which comprises Reed Specialist Recruitment, Reed Learning, Reed in Partnership and Reed Online. He is the son of [[Sir Alec Reed]], who founded the company in 1960. ==Education== Reed attended [[Scaitcliffe]] prep school and [[St Paul's School, London|St Paul's]]. He graduated from [[Christ Church, Oxford]] in 1984 with a degree in [[Philosophy, Politics and Economics]] (PPE,) and subsequently gained an [[MBA]] from the [[Harvard Business School]], where his father briefly joined him to study. At Oxford, Reed was political editor of ''Samizdat'', a magazine for political science students. At Harvard he produced a case study and video about slum improvement works in [[Addis Ababa]], Ethiopia. Titled ''In The Shadow of The City'',{{cite web|author1=James Reed|author2=Anne Donnelon|author3=Nicholas Richardson|title=In the Shadow of the City|url=http://hbr.org/product/in-the-shadow-of-the-city/an/490093-PDF-ENG|website=''HBR.Org''|publisher=Harvard|accessdate=26 August 2014}} the case study was taught at Harvard and other Universities. Reed was travel editor of Harbus News, the Harvard Business School's student news organisation. ==Early career== Reed's first job was in a cemetery, levelling graves at a burial site in Old Windsor. In an interview with [[The Independent]] newspaper in 2000 Reed said: "I got the job because an elderly lady asked my predecessor what he was doing digging up her husband's grave. He wasn't, but flippantly he said it was because her husband hadn't been paying the rates lately – and he got fired. It was miserable, it was cold, it was horrible and hard – and I didn't last very long at it." {{cite web|last1=Davies |first1=Clancy |title=Twenty Questions: James Reed, Chief Executive, Reed Executive |url=//www.independent.co.uk/student/postgraduate/mbas-guide/twenty-questions-james-reed-chief-executive-reed-exectutive-626185.html/ |website=The Independent |accessdate=30 July 2014 |date=22 November 2000 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090321205834/http://www.independent.co.uk/student/postgraduate/mbas-guide/twenty-questions-james-reed-chief-executive-reed-exectutive-626185.html/ |archivedate=21 March 2009 |df= }} After graduating from Oxford in 1984, Reed sought to work for an entrepreneur. He wrote a speculative job application to [[Gordon Roddick|Gordon]] and [[Anita Roddick]] of the [[Body Shop]] plc. The couple subsequently employed him as assistant to then-chairman Gordon. Reed has described his time at the Body Shop as his transition from University to the world of work. He has cited Anita Roddick as an influence, saying: "If a bottle of jojoba hand lotion wasn't displayed properly on the shelf, she'd pull you up on it. And I really liked that — that combination of real drive and enthusiasm, and getting the details right."{{cite web|last1=Doke|first1=DeeDee|title=Venturing into fresh fishing grounds|url=http://www.recruiter.co.uk/archive/part-27/Venturing-into-fresh-fishing-grounds|website=Recruiter|publisher=Redactive Publishing Limited|accessdate=29 July 2014|quote=She brought huge energy into her work and loved what she did. She also had incredible attention to detail.}} During 1985–1986 Reed worked as a [[media planner]]/buyer for [[Saatchi & Saatchi]] plc, where he planned and managed advertising campaigns for [[British Rail]], [[Club 18-30]], [[Eurotunnel]] and [[Procter and Gamble]]. From 1987 to 1988 Reed worked for [[Afghanaid]] and [[Help the Aged]], co-ordinating [[Disaster response|relief]] and [[International development|development]] programmes in [[Bangladesh]], [[Pakistan]] and Soviet-occupied [[Afghanistan]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.managementtoday.co.uk/james-reed-man-took-recruitment-online/entrepreneurs/article/1441257|title=James Reed: The man who took recruitment online|access-date=2018-03-02}} In Afghanistan he established a village assistance programme for farmers affected by regional conflict, co-ordinated fundraising, publicity and sponsorship services for Afghanaid and reported on the Afghan conflict for [[The Independent]] newspaper.{{cite web|last1=Reed|first1=James|title=How The Stinger has transformed the Afghan War|website=The Independent|date=23 December 1987}} To enter Afghanistan from Pakistan's border, Reed travelled disguised as an Afghan with a party of [[Mujahideen]] rebels.{{cite web|last1=Jones|first1=Lyndsey|title=Behind Enemy Lines: Relief worker's close-up view of the Afghan war|accessdate=29 July 2014|date=22 April 1988|quote=One of the officers told me to wear Afghan clothes and a turban and pretend to be asleep on the bus...so that's what I did and it was quite easy}} Following his graduation from Harvard in 1990, Reed began a two-year production course at the [[BBC]], where he worked as an Assistant Producer on documentaries and factual programmes. These included BBC TV's 'Business Matters', for which Reed produced ''Crazy Ways for Crazy Days'', a 50-minute documentary about management guru [[Tom Peters]], and ''The Pros and The Cons'', an inside view of [[private prison|prison privatisation]] at [[Strangeways]]. After the Tom Peters documentary grossed £1m, Reed requested funding to make a similar programme – but was turned down, leading him to grow dissatisfied with his employment at the BBC.{{cite book|author1=Alec Reed|author2=Judi Bevan|title=I Love Mondays: The autobiography of Sir Alec Reed CBE|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D-4NXg8qpcEC|date=5 January 2012|publisher=Profile Books|isbn=1-84765-767-2|pages=130–131}} Reed became a non-executive director of Reed in 1992. In a 2014 radio interview, Reed spoke of the circumstances leading up to joining the family business full-time:{{cite web | author=Best of the guest | author2=Best of the guest | author3=Best of the guest | last4=Effori | first4=Nilo | last5=Shapers | first5=Business | author6=Best of the guest | title=June 2014 | website=Business Shapers | date=2014-06-27 | url=https://businessshapers.co.uk/2014/06/ | access-date=2018-03-29}}
Joining the family business wasn't a ''fait accompli''. When my father got to 60 he said 'James, there's not much point having a family business if there isn't anyone in the family in it, and I'm getting to the age where I have to think about these things'. I'd been sitting on the fence for some time. Then one day he said: ‘That job that I have been talking to you about? It’s going to be in [[The Sunday Times]] ''Appointments'' section next week – do you want to apply or not?" That got me off the fence! I was fearful of following him. He was a very successful entrepreneur who'd set up this business and he was well loved in the business. I was worried about failing. That fear of failure probably kept me on the fence for longer than it should have done.
==Reed Group== Reed joined the [[Reed (company)|Reed Group]] full-time in April 1994, as director of operations. He became Chief executive in February 1997.{{cite web|last1=Hirschkorn|first1=Jenny|title=Interview: A Family Affair|url=https://www.accountancylive.com/interview-family-affair|website=Accountancy Live|publisher=Wolters Kluwer|accessdate=29 July 2014|date=April 2002}} To symbolise the handover of control of the company, Reed's father presented him with a conductor's baton mounted in a glass case. The baton now hangs on the wall of Reed's personal office at the company's headquarters in Covent Garden, London.{{cite book|author1=Alec Reed|author2=Judi Bevan|title=I Love Mondays: The autobiography of Sir Alec Reed CBE|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D-4NXg8qpcEC|date=5 January 2012|publisher=Profile Books|isbn=1-84765-767-2}} In press interviews, Reed is often asked to respond to the accusation that his appointment to the family business was an act of [[nepotism]]; he has consistently offered unqualified agreement. In a 2010 ''Guardian'' interview he said "There is no other way of describing it",{{cite web|last1=Teather|first1=David|title=Alec and James Reed: recruitment is just the job for father and son|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2010/jun/03/alec-james-reed-recruitment#start-of-comments|website=The Guardian|publisher=Scott Trust|date=3 June 2010|quote="It was quite a big deal for me. I was only 34 and it was a bit sooner than I had expected}} and in a 2013 interview with Associated Newspapers he said: ‘The family joke is that I had a 30-year interview and eventually got in’.{{cite web|last1=Owen|first1=Vicki|title=I don't like the zero hours deal either – but it's better than no work at all': James Reed on controversial pay plans|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-2384105/James-Reed-speaks-controversial-zero-hour-contracts.html|website=Daily Mail|accessdate=26 August 2014}}{{Citation|title=BLM interviews James Reed of Reed Recruitment|url=https://soundcloud.com/business-leader/blm-interviews-james-reed-of-reed-recruitment|language=en|access-date=2018-10-08}} Reed's father is quoted as believing that family-run businesses "...cut out a lot of company politics".{{cite book|author1=Colin Barrow|author2=Robert Brown|author3=Liz Clarke|title=The Business Enterprise Handbook|quote=You know the MD won't be headhunted|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fNLmmtAt1QMC|accessdate=4 August 2014|year=2004|publisher=Kogan Page Publishers|isbn=978-0-7494-4100-5|page=344}} Reed succeeded his father to the position of chairman in 2004.{{cite web|last1=Duff|first1=Charlie|title=James Reed: The three Rs - recruitment, retention and relationships|url=http://www.hrzone.com/topic/recruitment/james-reed-3-rs-recruitment-retention-and-relationships/104914|website=HR Zone|accessdate=30 July 2014|date=20 July 2010}} Reed has said that he considers his three most significant contributions to the Reed Group to be the development of reed.co.uk, the advent of Reed in Partnership and the globalisation of the company.{{cite news|title=Ten Minutes with….James Reed|url=http://www.theemployable.com/index.php/2012/01/24/ten-minutes-with-james-reed-chairman-of-reed/|accessdate=30 July 2014|date=24 January 2012}} Under his leadership the company's turnover has grown from £150m to £1bn.{{Cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/business/2018/09/04/taking-ceo-make-success-succession/|title=Taking over from a CEO: How to make a success of succession|last=Christie|first=Sophie|date=2018-09-04|work=The Telegraph|access-date=2018-09-27|language=en-GB|issn=0307-1235}} In 2018 he was named to the ''Europe Staffing 100'' list of recruitment professionals, published by ''Staffing Industry Analysis.''{{Cite news|url=http://si100europe.staffingindustry.com/2018/08/james-reed-5/|title=James Reed|work=The Staffing 100 (Europe)|access-date=2018-09-27|language=en-US}} ===Welfare-to-work (Reed in Partnership)=== In 1997 the-then [[Paymaster General]] [[Geoffrey Robinson]] invited Reed to bid for the inaugural contracts issued by the newly elected [[Blair ministry|Blair Government]] which, as part of its [[New Deal (United Kingdom)|New Deal]] programme, saw some of the traditional work of [[Active labour market policies|Job Centres]] outsourced to the private sector. As of 2011, Reed in Partnership employed 900 staff. Reed has expanded the business into Poland and Australia. ===De-listing=== As chief executive, Reed delisted Reed Executive from the UK Stock Exchange in 2003, buying back the company for 140p per share, at a valuation of £62.6 million and at an 18% premium to the previous day's closing price. Shares in Reed Executive rose 15% following the announcement.{{cite web|title=Reed Executive to go private|url=http://www.stockmarketwire.com/article/68181/Reed-Executive-to-go-private.html|website=''StockMarketWire.com''|accessdate=4 August 2014|date=4 April 2003|quote=Due to negative market sentiment towards smaller quoted companies and the increasing illiquidity of the Reed Ordinary Shares, the directors of James Reed & Partners believe that the benefits to the company of maintaining its listing have been significantly eroded.}} At the time, some financial commentators suggested that the Reed family were taking advantage of a lull in the firm's share price, in the wake of both a cyclical downturn and the controversy over Reed's decision to spin off Reed Health.{{cite web|last1=George|first1=Jemma|title=Reed Executive jumps on MBO move|url=http://citywire.co.uk/money/reed-executive-jumps-on-mbo-move/a247309|website=''Citywire.co.uk''|accessdate=4 August 2014|date=4 April 2004|quote=There was nothing to suggest trading would improve in the short-term, which is in keeping with the message from others in the sector such as Robert Walters, Michael Page, PSD and Whitehead Mann...their share prices continue to languish at new lows creating opportunities for corporate action.}}{{cite web|last1=Prynn|first1=Jonathan|title=Reed sackings put Sawyer on spot|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-1531726/Reed-sackings-put-Sawyer-on-spot.html|website=This is Money|accessdate=31 July 2014|date=2 December 2002|quote=In what is reckoned to be an unprecedented act...Alec Reed voted without warning to block the reappointment of chief executive Christa Echtle and finance director Desmond Doyle, effectively terminating their contracts on the spot. Echtle...believes Alec Reed intervened because of a resolution at the annual meeting to issue new shares to fund acquisitions. It is understood Alec Reed did not want a dilution of his controlling holding in the company.}} Two years later Reed would launch a £38m hostile takeover for Reed Health, following which the company eventually came back under the Reed family's control. Reed stated that the firm was delisted because it no longer had need of outside capital. In his autobiography, Reed's father suggested that the de-listing was due in part to the publication of the [[Review of the role and effectiveness of non-executive directors|Higgs]] and [[Cadbury Report|Cadbury]] reports into public company governance, both of which called for wide-ranging restrictions upon directors and their appointments. ===reed.co.uk=== reed.co.uk was the first recruitment website offered by a recruitment agency in the UK.{{cite web|title=E-MAIL US YOUR CV, PLEASE|url=http://www.managementtoday.co.uk/news/410511/UK-E-MAIL-US-CV-PLEASE/?DCMP=ILC-SEARCH|website=Management Today|accessdate=4 August 2014}} It launched in 1995 with 40 vacancies. It now advertises over 200,000 vacancies a day. In interview, Reed has made light of the fact that the company's first website was suggested and built by a young IT contractor nicknamed "Pancake the Clown", after his sideline business as a children's entertainer. In a 2014 interview with JazzFM, Reed said: "The truth of the matter is, I got Pancake the Clown to build our first prototype"{{cite web|title=Business Shapers – James Reed|url=http://businessshapers.co.uk/2014/06/|website=JazzFM|accessdate=4 August 2014}} Reed has also spoken of being "horrified" when a young member of staff suggested that the firm should open up its website to vacancies offered by rival recruitment firms. Reed would go on to approve the experiment; the scheme began in May 2000 and by November of the same year over 2000 rival firms had registered on the site. Reed would go on to credit the idea as being the foundation of the firm's online strategy; the junior staff member was paid a £100,000 bonus for his suggestion.{{cite web|last1=Doke|first1=DeeDee|title=Venturing into fresh fishing grounds|url=http://www.recruiter.co.uk/archive/part-27/Venturing-into-fresh-fishing-grounds/|website=''Recruiter.co.uk''|accessdate=31 July 2014|date=31 July 2004}} ===Media commentary=== Reed regularly comments in the media on employment issues, including apprenticeships,{{cite web | title=CEO Today Magazine March 2018 Edition | website=FlippingBook | date=2018-03-19 | url=http://www.ceotodaymagazine.com/issues/2018/03/19/ | access-date=2018-03-29}}{{cite web | title='A society that truly embraces apprenticeships will revolutionise work' | website=Tes | date=2018-03-27 | url=https://www.tes.com/news/further-education/breaking-views/a-society-truly-embraces-apprenticeships-will-revolutionise | access-date=2018-03-29}} automation,{{Cite web|url=http://www.recruiter.co.uk/news/2017/11/don%E2%80%99t-fear-rise-machine-says-james-reed|title=Don’t fear the rise of the machine says James Reed {{!}} Recruiter|website=www.recruiter.co.uk|language=en|access-date=2018-03-02}} zero-hours contracts,{{cite web|url=http://thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-2384105/James-Reed-speaks-controversial-zero-hour-contracts.html/|title='I don't like the zero hours deal either – but it's better than no work at all': James Reed on controversial pay plans|last1=Owen|first1=Vicki|date=3 August 2013|website=This Is Money|accessdate=31 July 2014|quote='I don't like zero-hour jobs, don't get me wrong, but they are part of the scene'}} workplace skills, summer jobs,{{Cite news|url=https://www.fenews.co.uk/featured-article/228-apprenticeships/18504-why-summer-work-experience-is-so-important|title=Why summer work experience is so important|last=Reed|first=James|work=FE News|access-date=2018-08-16|language=en-gb}} taxation reform for family businesses and improving opportunities for prisoners and ex-prisoners.{{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/847fba84-eddd-11e0-a491-00144feab49a.html|title=Give prisoners better chance to find work, say company chiefs|last1=Warrell|first1=Helen|date=3 October 2011|website=Financial Times|publisher=Pearson|accessdate=31 July 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/business/economics/article3225563.ece|title=Family firms call for help to remain going concerns|last1=Clark|first1=Andrew|date=14 November 2011|website=The Times|accessdate=4 August 2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.recruiter.co.uk/archive/part-29/It-works--when-you-put-your-mind-to-it/|title=It works, when you put your mind to it|website=''Recruiter.co.uk''|accessdate=31 July 2014}} He has called for state contracts to be held back from firms that deliberately delay payment to creditors; citing the collapse of Carillion and the £2bn it owed to its suppliers, Reed has characterised such firms as "drunk-drivers". He has also encouraged school-leavers to consider joining the workplace instead of attending university, and has called upon Oxbridge universities to increase their intake by doubling their semesters.{{Cite news|url=https://www.fenews.co.uk/fevoices/17568-opening-up-oxbridge|title=Widening Participation - What Oxbridge can do to diversify more|last=Reed|first=James|work=FE News|access-date=2018-06-18|language=en-gb}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.thisismoney.co.uk/money/news/article-5320257/Stop-giving-state-contracts-late-payers-says-Reed.html?ito=email_share_article-top|title=Stop giving state contracts to late payers, says Reed|work=This is Money|access-date=2018-01-30}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/news/education/jobs-boss-talented-teens-don-t-all-need-university-a3651116.html|title=Jobs boss: Talented teens don’t all need university|work=Evening Standard|access-date=2018-01-30|language=en-GB}}{{cite web | last=Haworth | first=Elliott | title=Firms 'doing a Carillion' will murder small businesses, says REED chairman | website=City A.M. | date=2018-02-05 | url=http://www.cityam.com/279990/firms-doing-carillion-murder-small-businesses-says-reed | access-date=2018-02-08}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.ibtimes.co.uk/end-scandal-90-day-payments-what-we-must-learn-carillion-collapse-1664460|title=End the scandal of 90-day payments: What we must learn from the Carillion collapse|last=Reed|first=James|date=2018-02-28|work=International Business Times UK|access-date=2018-03-02|language=en}} Reed is a Fellow of the [[Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development]] (CIPD). He was formerly an Associate of the Prime Minister's Delivery Unit and a member of the [[Institute for Public Policy Research]] (IPPR)'s business-led Taskforce on Race Equality and Diversity in the Private Sector. In the run-up to the [[2010 general election (UK)|2010 general election]], Reed conducted public video-interviews with the three Parliamentary candidates nominated for the role of Secretary of State ([[Steve Webb]], [[Yvette Cooper]] and [[Theresa May]]), asking questions sent in by job hunters.{{cite web|title=Reed.co.uk Election interviews|url=https://www.youtube.com/user/reedvote2010|via=YouTube|accessdate=31 July 2014}} For the [[United Kingdom general election, 2017|2017 general election]], Reed's cross-party interviews were conducted with [[Damian Hinds|Damien Hinds]],{{Citation|last=reed.co.uk|title=Damian Hinds (Conservative) interviewed by James Reed|date=2017-06-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B-Ax-62EJOo|accessdate=2018-02-05}} [[Debbie Abrahams]]{{Citation|last=reed.co.uk|title=Debbie Abrahams (Labour) interviewed by James Reed|date=2017-06-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=V9b0zZP_upk|accessdate=2018-02-05}} and [[Susan Kramer, Baroness Kramer|Baroness Kramer]].{{Citation|last=reed.co.uk|title=Baroness Kramer (Liberal Democrats) interviewed by James Reed|date=2017-06-05|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bazSVsQTRdg|accessdate=2018-02-05}} ==Television appearances== Since 2008, Reed has been depicted in a series of humorous TV adverts featuring the actor and comedian [[Rufus Jones (actor)|Rufus Jones]]. Some of these adverts have been directed by the previous year's winners of Reed's annual Short Film Competition.{{cite web|title=Street 40|quote=4m23s |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jAW4pPeO9V4|via=YouTube|accessdate=30 July 2014}} The adverts begin with Jones introducing himself as James Reed. Jones' portrayal of Reed is a knowingly [[over acting|over-acted]] caricature of a comic book superhero, one who has the [[superpower (ability)|superpower]] to transform job-hunters into their ideal vocation.{{cite web|title=Reed.co.uk launches major TV campaign|url=http://www.onrec.com/news/news-archive/reedcouk-launches-major-tv-campaign|website=''OnRec.com''|accessdate=31 July 2014}} In one advert Reed makes a [[cameo appearance]] as an ice cream seller who is transformed into a nightclub DJ by the character of James Reed as played by Jones. The adverts have received more than 28 million YouTube views.{{cite web|url = https://www.youtube.com/user/reedcouk/about|publisher = YouTube|title = Analytics for ReedOnline|accessdate = 21 December 2015}} The 2016 TV campaign sees Jones playing Reed as a comic knight. Reed has made appearances in [[The Apprentice (UK series eleven)|Series 11]] and [[The Apprentice (UK series thirteen)|Series 13]] of BBC Television's [[The Apprentice (UK TV series)|The Apprentice]]. ==Philanthropy== Reed is a trustee of several Reed family charitable initiatives, including The Reed Foundation and [[The Big Give]] Trust. The Big Give was founded by James's father [[Alec Reed|Sir Alec Reed]] in 2007 and has helped to raise £82m for UK-registered charities. ===Grenfell Tower appeal=== Reed's family home in London is within sight of Grenfell Tower. After witnessing the Grenfell Tower fire at first hand, Reed set up a Big Give charity appeal which raised £1m within 48 hours of the fire breaking out. The appeal went on to raise £2.6m before being closed in September 2017. Reed donated £100,000 of his own money and The Reed Foundation donated a further £100,000, alongside donations made by members of the public, businesses and local organisations. The appeal's proceeds were donated to The K&C Foundation. Reed has called for some of the appeal proceeds to be spent on an educational centre for residents of the area to learn coding and other digital skills, as part of a wider project to form a hub of digital companies in North Kensington.{{cite web | title=Reed Chairman makes plea to push The Big Give matching fund for Grenfell Tower victims to £3m | website=City Philanthropy | date=22 June 2017 | url=http://www.cityphilanthropy.org.uk/news/reed-chairman-makes-plea-push-big-give-matching-fund-grenfell-tower-victims-%C2%A33m | access-date=15 November 2017}}{{cite web | title=Big Give Grenfell appeal raises £2.6m: its biggest ever total for an individual cause | website=UK Fundraising | date=7 September 2017 | url=https://fundraising.co.uk/2017/09/07/big-give-grenfell-appeal-raises-2-6m-biggest-ever-total-individual-cause/ | access-date=15 November 2017}} ==Publications== ===''Put Your Mindset to Work''=== Coauthored by Reed and Harvard lecturer Paul G. Stoltz, ''Put Your Mindset to Work'' was published by [[Portfolio Penguin]] in May 2011. The book offers research data underlining the importance of employee mindset, citing that 97% of employers would put mindset ahead of skill set when recruiting. The book goes on to identify three elements of a competitive employment mindset, namely ''Global, Good'' and ''Grit'', which the authors summarise as "the 3G's". ''Global'' is said to measure an employee's ability to set their actions and decisions in a global context; ''Good'' refers to an employee's interpersonal sensitivity and a desire to do good for others; ''Grit'' references an employee's tenacity and intensity in the workplace.{{cite web|last1=Chynoweth|first1=Carly|title=Attitude is worth more than skills|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/public/Appointments/article643235.ece|website=''SundayTimes.co.uk''|accessdate=4 August 2014|date=6 June 2011|quote=Back in the worst days of the financial crisis in 2008 I went to a seminar and one of the speakers said 'the problem is we don't know what skills will be most in demand in 10 years'. I remember thinking 'no, of course we don't, but I do know the people I will want to hire', and it was all about mindset."}} ''Put Your Mindset to Work'' was awarded the [[Chartered Management Institute|CMI]] Management Book of the Year Award in the Commuters' Read category.{{cite web|title=CMI: Management Book of the Year 2012 – Dame Mary Marsh|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ra0lbx5IU7Q&feature=youtu.be|via=YouTube|publisher=CMI|accessdate=4 August 2014|date=February 2012}} The book entered the ''USA Today'' best-seller list in June 2011.{{cite web|title=Put Your Mindset to Work|url=http://books.usatoday.com/book/james-reed-paul-g-stoltz-put-your-mindset-to-work/l31732|website=USA Today|accessdate=4 August 2014}} A second edition of the work was published in August 2013, with jacket endorsements from [[Timpson (retailer)|Timpson]] CEO James Timpson, Gordon Roddick and management author Jim Kouzes. ===''Why You: 101 Interview Questions You'll Never Fear Again''=== Reed's second book with Penguin Portfolio features examples of interview questions and strategies for answering them, based on research obtained from Reed's network of hirers, recruiters and interviewees.{{cite web|title=Why You? 101 WAYS TO SHINE AT INTERVIEW|url=http://www.penguin.co.uk/nf/Book/BookDisplay/0,,9780241970218,00.html|website=''Penguin.co.uk''|accessdate=31 July 2014}} The book's premise is that all interview questions are variations on just 15 distinct themes, referred to as "The Fateful Fifteen". Reed encourages candidates to relate all interview questions to these 15 themes, while cautioning against preparing canned answers in advance, arguing that this approach gets in the way of genuine and spontaneous conversation. Bookbag.co.uk awarded the title a "Highly Recommended" in its review section;{{cite web|author1=Lesley Mason|title=Why You? 101 Interview Questions You'll Never Fear Again by James Reed|url=http://www.thebookbag.co.uk/reviews/index.php?title=Why_You%3F_101_Interview_Questions_You%27ll_Never_Fear_Again_by_James_Reed|website=''TheBookbag.co.uk''|accessdate=1 February 2016}} The Notting Hill Post called the book "...essential reading"{{cite web|author1=Mary-Lu Bakker|title=HOW TO BE A GOOD INTERVIEWEE … BUT DON'T FORGET YOUR SHIRT|url=http://nottinghillpost.com/news/james-reed/|website=The Notting Hill Post|accessdate=1 February 2016}} ==Personal life== Reed is married to Nicola; they live in London and Wiltshire. They have six children. His hobbies are said to include running, riding and driving horses, football and mountaineering. He has participated in two of Reed's annual Alpine Leadership Challenges led by the [[alpinist]] Stefan Gatt. Reed has identified his father as the person he most admires in the recruitment industry, and King Alfred the Great as his boyhood hero.{{cite web|last1=Jacobs|first1=Emma|title=20 questions: James Reed|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/dd89c4fc-b3c3-11e0-855b-00144feabdc0.html|website=Financial Times|publisher=Pearson|accessdate=31 July 2014|date=July 2011|quote=My boyhood hero, King Alfred the Great. He wasn't very good about the house but he transformed the country for the better and gave the Vikings a good thrashing.}} ==Awards== In 2018 he was named ''Top CEO'' in [[Glassdoor]]'s ''Employees' Choice'' awards.{{Cite web|url=https://www.glassdoor.co.uk/Award/Top-CEOs-UK-LST_KQ0,11.htm|title=Top CEOs UK|website=Glassdoor|language=en|access-date=2018-07-03}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.reed.co.uk/ Reed.co.uk] {{Employment}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Reed, James A.}} [[Category:1963 births]] [[Category:20th-century British businesspeople]] [[Category:Alumni of Christ Church, Oxford]] [[Category:British business writers]] [[Category:British business executives]] [[Category:Harvard Business School alumni]] [[Category:Human resource management people]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Woking]]

{{Infobox person | name = James Mworia | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1978}} | birth_place = [[Kenya]] | death_date = | death_place = | education = '''[[University of Nairobi]]'''
{{small|([[Bachelor of Laws]])}}
'''[[Certified Public Accountant| Certified Public Accountants of Kenya]]'''
{{small|([[Certified Public Accountant]])}}
'''[[Strathmore University]]'''
{{small|([[Chartered Financial Analyst]])}} | occupation = [[Business Executive]], [[Lawyer]] & [[Accountant]] | years_active = 2001 — present | nationality = [[Kenya]]n | citizenship = [[Kenya]] | residence = [[Nairobi]], [[Kenya]] | known_for = [[Business Administration]] | networth = | home_town = [[Nairobi]] | title = [[Managing Director]] & [[CEO]]
[[Centum Investments]] | spouse = '''{{small|Mrs. Mworia}}''' }} '''James Mwirigi Mworia''' is a [[Kenya]]n lawyer, accountant, and business executive. He is the managing director and chief executive officer of [[Centum Investments]],{{cite web|accessdate=13 June 2014| url=https://www.forbes.com/pictures/ehed45lik/james-mworia-kenyan-chief-executive-officer-centum-investments/|title=James Mworia, Kenyan, Chief Executive Officer, Centum Investments|publisher=[[Forbes Magazine]]}} the largest publicly traded private capital firm in eastern Africa.{{cite web|accessdate=13 June 2014|url=http://www.kenyanmagazines.com/james-mworia-ceo-centum-investments-the-business-of-investing-management-august-2010/| first=Brenda|last=Otindo|date=August 2010|title=James Mworia, CEO Centum Investments|publisher=Management Magazine via Kenyanmagazines.com}} He has served in that capacity since 2008. ==Background and education== Mworia was born in 1978. He attended Alliance High School, [[Strathmore University]], and the [[University of Nairobi]]. He has a [[Bachelor of Laws]] from Nairobi University. He is also a [[certified public accountant]] and a [[chartered financial analyst]].{{cite web|accessdate=13 June 2014| url=http://www.strathmore.edu/alumni/strathmore-taught-me-excellence-says-ceo/ |title=Strathmore Taught Me Excellence, Says CEO| publisher=[[Strathmore University]]}} ==Work history== In 2001, Mworia began working as a filing clerk at Centum Investments. Despite having a law degree and several other financial and accounting diplomas and certificates, he accepted this entry-level position. He gradually rose through the ranks, and in 2005 he was appointed chief investment officer at Centum Investments. He served in that position until December 2006, when he joined [[TransCentury Investments]] as its head of investments.{{cite web|accessdate=26 June 2015 |author=Reuters| url=http://uk.reuters.com/business/quotes/officerProfile?symbol=ICDC.NR&officerId=1260206|title = Centum Investment Company - Profile of Mworia, James|date=2014|publisher=[[Reuters.com]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.howwemadeitinafrica.com/how-kenyas-james-mworia-rose-from-intern-to-ceo-in-seven-years/ |title=How Kenya’s James Mworia rose from intern to CEO in seven years| accessdate=20 September 2016| first= Dinfin| last= Mulupi | date=19 August 2015 | location=Cape Town| publisher=Howwemadeitinafrica.com}} In 2008, at age 30, he was appointed chief executive officer (CEO) and managing director at Centum.{{cite web|accessdate=13 June 2014| url=http://www.capitalfm.co.ke/business/2014/06/mworia-from-intern-to-ceo-of-fast-growing-centum/|title=Mworia: From Intern to CEO of Fast Growing Centum|first=Margaret|last=Wahito|date=11 June 2014| publisher=Capitalfm.co.ke}} During his first six years as CEO, Centum increased its asset base from KES:6 billion (US$69 million) to approximately KES:30 billion (US$350 million).{{cite web|title=Centum Posts Improved Annual Profit After Tax| url=http://www.ventures-africa.com/2014/06/centum-posts-improved-annual-profit-after-tax/|publisher=Ventures Africa Magazine|date=10 June 2014|first=Mzwandile|last=Jacks|accessdate=13 June 2014}} ==Other responsibilities== He serves as the chairman of the board of directors at [[Sidian Bank]].{{cite web|accessdate=30 September 2016|newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]]| url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/James-Mworia-Law-intern-who-rose-to-best-paid-CEO-in-Kenya/539444-3399968-12kt5ixz/index.html | date=30 September 2016 | title=James Mworia: Law intern who rose to best paid CEO in Kenya | first= Brian | last=Ngugi | location=Nairobi}} He also serves as a board member at the [[Nairobi Stock Exchange]] (NSE), effective June 2015.{{cite web|access-date=26 June 2015 |date=25 June 2015 |last=John Gachiri | url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Centum-s-Mworia-takes-Ciano-NSE-board-position-/-/539552/2765366/-/13mm346/-/index.html | title=Centum’s Mworia Takes Ciano NSE Board Position |first=and Simon Ciuri |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |location=Nairobi}} In June 2018, he is expected to leave the board of the NSE, having served his three year term, and having declined to offer himself for re-election.{{cite web|title=Mworia, Mbaru to leave the NSE board of directors |access-date=8 May 2018 |date=8 May 2018 |first=James | last=Ngunjiri |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |location=Nairobi}} In September 2016, he was named the highest paid executive among the five largest corporations in Kenya, with an annual compensation package valued at KES:201.1 million (approx. US$2 million) annually.{{cite web| newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |access-date=20 September 2016 |date=19 September 2016 |title=Centum’s Mworia tops list of Kenya’s best paid executives | url=http://www.businessdailyafrica.com/Corporate-News/Centum-s-Mworia-tops-list-of-Kenya-s-best-paid-executives/539550-3386730-kehj0y/index.html | location=Nairobi | first=Victor | last=Juma}} ==Personal life== According to a 2011 published report, James Mworia is a married father.{{cite web | date=14 September 2011 |accessdate=20 September 2016 | url=http://africanmillionaire.net/2011/09/millionaire-james-mworia-kenyan-ceo-of | title= Millionaire James Mworia, Kenyan CEO of Centum Investments, East Africa's Largest Equity Firm | publisher=Africanmillionaire.net | author=B. Otindo}} ==See also== * [[Nairobi Securities Exchange]] * [[Uganda Securities Exchange]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/tutuschildren/2012/12/2012123151450144123.html Tutu's Children - James Mworia: 'Being World Class'] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mworia James}} [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:University of Nairobi alumni]] [[Category:Kikuyu people]] [[Category:Strathmore University alumni]] [[Category:Kenyan accountants]] [[Category:Kenyan lawyers]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:CFA charterholders]] [[Category:Kenyan business executives]]

[[File:Leif Johansson 2014-07-15 001.jpg|thumbnail|Leif Johansson in 2014]] '''Leif Valdemar Johansson''' (born 30 September 1951), is a Swedish businessman. He was President and CEO of the [[Volvo Group]] from 1997 to 2011 and is Chairman of [[Ericsson]] since 2011 and of [[AstraZeneca|AstraZeneca plc]]. In 2012, the ''[[Fokus (magazine)|Fokus Magazine]]'' ranked him as Sweden's 6th most powerful person.[http://www.fokus.se/makthavarlistan/ Leif Johansson is now Sweden's 6th most powerful person, up from 28th last year.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130926145948/http://www.fokus.se/makthavarlistan/ |date=2013-09-26 }} ==Background== Johansson was born on August 30, 1951, in [[Gothenburg]], [[Sweden]]. His father was Lennart Johansson, for many years President of the [[SKF]] Group (1971-1985). He and his wife Eva have five children. ==Education== *1958-1971 primary education, Gothenburg *1968 Chatsworth High School, [[Chatsworth, California|Chatsworth]], [[California]] *1971 matriculation, natural sciences, Kjellbergska Gymnasiet, Gothenburg *1972 [[Sergeant#Sweden|Sergeant]], [[Swedish Air Force]] *1977 [[Master of Science]] in [[Mechanical Engineering]], [[Chalmers University of Technology]], [[Gothenburg]] ==Career== Johansson has worked in Swedish industry for most of his professional life. He assumed his first position as Managing Director in 1978 (age of 27), at [[Husqvarna Motorcycles]]. In 1982 he became President of [[Facit]], an office machines manufacturer, followed by ten years with white-goods manufacturer [[Electrolux]] where he eventually advanced to the position of CEO. In 1997 Johansson was appointed President and CEO of Volvo in Gothenburg, a position he held until 2011. 1974-76 project consultant, [[Indevo]]
1977 product developer and assistant to the President, [[Centro-Maskin]]
1979 President of [[Husqvarna Motorcycles]]
1981 Divisional Manager Office Machines, [[Facit]] Sweden
1982 President of Facit
1984 Divisional Manager, AB [[Electrolux]], white-goods
1987 President of AB Electrolux, white-goods
1988 Vice President, AB Electrolux
1991 President of AB Electrolux
1994 CEO, Electrolux
1997 President and CEO, [[Volvo Group]]
2011 Chairman, [[Ericsson]] ==Other assignments== Chairman of the Board: AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals LP
Member of the Board: [[Bristol-Myers Squibb Company]], [[Svenska Cellulosa Aktiebolaget]] (SCA), [[Confederation of Swedish Enterprise]]
Member of [[Royal Swedish Academy of Engineering Sciences]] (IVA)
Chairman ERT [[European Round Table of Industrialists]] ==Awards== *1977 Marcus Wallenberg ASEA Award *2001 [[H. M. The King's Medal]] 12th size in the Ribbon of the [[Royal Order of the Seraphim]] *2005 The [[Royal Automobile Club (Sweden)|Royal Automobile Club]]'s Gold Memorial Medal *2005 Knight of the National Order of the [[Legion of Honour]], France *2006 Honorary Doctor at the [[Blekinge Institute of Technology]] *2007 Honorary Doctor of Medicine at the [[University of Gothenburg]] *2009 The Mekanprisma Award *2013 Officer of the Legion of Honour ==Volvo Group== The [[Volvo Group]] is one of the world's largest suppliers of commercial vehicles with products such as trucks, buses, construction equipment, drive systems for marine and industrial applications, and aircraft engine components. The [[Volvo Group]] also offers its customers financial services. Today the Group has customers in more than 180 countries worldwide, mainly in Europe, Asia and North America. The Group has about 100,000 employees and production facilities in 19 countries. Decisions adopted under Johansson's leadership:
1998 Acquisition of [[Samsung]]'s excavator operation, South Korea
1999 Sale of [[Volvo Cars]] to [[Ford Motor Company]]
2001 Acquisition of [[Renault Trucks]], France, and [[Mack Trucks]], USA
2006 Acquisition of [[Nissan Diesel]], Japan
2007 Acquisition of [[Ingersoll Rand]]'s road construction machinery division, USA
2008 Agreement on joint venture company with [[Eicher Motors]], India == References == *[http://www.volvogroup.com/group/global/en-gb/investors/corporate_governance/ceo_gem/pages/ceo.aspx Profile at volvogroup.com] ==External links== {{commonscat|Leif Johansson}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Johansson, Leif Valdemar}} [[Category:1951 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:Swedish chief executives in the automobile industry]] [[Category:Swedish engineers]] [[Category:Volvo people]] [[Category:Chalmers University of Technology alumni]] [[Category:Chevaliers of the Légion d'honneur]] [[Category:20th-century Swedish businesspeople]] [[Category:20th-century engineers]] [[Category:Swedish Air Force personnel]]

{{redirect|MaRS|the planet|Mars||Mars (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox organization | name = MaRS Discovery District | logo = Metallic MaRS.jpg | logo_size = 100px | type = [[Charitable trust]] | founded_date = May 31, 2000 | location = [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada | origins = | key_people = [[Yung Wu]], [[chief executive officer|CEO]] | focus = [[Technology transfer]], [[commercialization]] | method = [[Consultancy]], [[market research]], [[venture capital]] | revenue = | num_volunteers = | owner = | Non-profit_slogan = | homepage = {{URL|http://www.marsdd.com/}} | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''MaRS Discovery District''' is a not-for-profit corporation founded in [[Toronto]], Ontario, Canada in 2000. Its stated goal is to commercialize publicly funded medical research and other technologies with the help of local private enterprises and as such is a [[public-private partnership]].<ref name="How did MaRS get started">{{cite web|url=http://www.marsdd.com/aboutmars/story/ |title=How did MaRS get started |accessdate=29 December 2013}}</ref> As part of its mission MaRS says, "MaRS helps create successful global businesses from Canada's science, technology and social innovation."<ref>{{cite web|title=Our mission, our vision {{!}} MaRS|url=http://www.marsdd.com/aboutmars/mission/|accessdate=29 April 2013}}</ref> {{As of|2014}}, [[Startup company|startup companies]] emerging from MaRS had created more than 4,000 jobs, and in the period of 2011 to 2014 had raised over $750 million in [[capital investments]].<ref name=philipiddis2014>{{Cite news|url=http://www.genengnews.com/gen-articles/incubators-blossom-along-with-their-startups/5245/|title=Incubators Blossom along with Their Startups|last=Philipiddis|first=Alex|date=15 June 2014|work=[[Gen. Eng. Biotechnol. News|Genetic Engineering & Biotechnology News]]|issue=12|volume=34|pages=7–8|access-date=2016-07-17}}</ref>
The name MaRS was originally drawn from a file name, and later attributed with the title "Medical and Related Sciences." It has since abandoned this association<ref name="How did MaRS get started"/> as it also works in other fields such as [[information and communications technology]], [[engineering]], and [[social innovation]].
== Facilities == [[Image:MaRSfromCollege.jpg|250 px|thumb|The MaRS Centre, seen from the northeast corner of College Street and University Avenue]] [[Image:MaRSPhase2Construction.JPG|250 px|thumb|Construction of MaRS Phase II in August 2008.]] [[Image:MaRSPhase2Construction3.JPG|250 px|thumb|The empty construction of MaRS Phase II in July 2009.]] [[Image:MaRSPhase2-3.jpg|250 px|thumb|Completed MaRS Phase 2 in 2016.]] [[File:AirbnbToronto2.jpg|thumb|Airbnb office in the MaRS Centre]] It is located on the corner of [[College Street (Toronto)|College Street]] and [[University Avenue (Toronto)|University Avenue]] in the city of Toronto’s [[Discovery District]], adjacent to the [[University of Toronto]] and its affiliated research hospitals at the [[University Health Network]].
The MaRS development consists of two phases.
=== Phase 1 === MaRS Discovery District Phase 1 was designed by Adamson Associates Architects and includes:
* The Heritage Building (formerly a wing of the [[Toronto General Hospital]]), * The Atrium * The South Tower * The Toronto Medical Discovery Tower
====The Heritage Building==== Inside the Heritage Building's four-storey brick façade (preserved) are tenant spaces occupied by professional services, industry associations, pharmaceutical companies and offices of Canadian universities and the [[Province of Ontario]]. In 2006, the MaRS Centre received the Heritage Toronto Award of Excellence for Architectural Conservation and Craftsmanship. The building was designed by [[Pearson and Darling]] and opened in 1911.
====The Atrium==== The MaRS atrium is a glass-roofed public thoroughfare that provides walkway access to Heritage Building tenants and retail vendors, as well as access to the South and Medical Discovery Towers. Its bottom level features a sub-dividable conference area that hosts public and private events. MaRS encourages events from across Toronto's arts, culture and broader urban community. The Atrium's lower level also features a media centre, video conferencing rooms and a public food court.
====The South Tower==== This eight-storey structure houses incubator programs and shared laboratory and research facilities. The {{convert|200000|sqft|m2|adj=on}}, wet-lab-capable building spans eight floors in the MaRS Centre. The tower boasts advanced mechanical and electrical systems, floors with enhanced load bearing capabilities and {{convert|15|ft|m|adj=on}} slab-to-slab clearances.
Occupying the second and third floors of the South Tower — directly above the MaRS corporate offices, is the MaRS Incubator – a dedicated space that houses offices and laboratories for approximately two dozen life science and technology firms.
====Toronto Medical Discovery Tower==== With {{convert|400000|sqft|m2}} of state-of-the-art wet labs, the 15-storey Toronto Medical Discovery Tower accommodates leading-edge scientific equipment and houses the basic research activities of two of Canada's premier research hospitals: the University Health Network and the Hospital for Sick Children.
Situated on the corner of College and Elizabeth Street, the building was designed with typical research and development lab floors configured with a side core arrangement and sheathed in metal and glass. The tower portions rest on a three-storey limestone podium that aligns with the heights of the adjoining College Wing and the formal landscape forecourt that extends the full block.
The shell and core of the TMDT is designed to accommodate a full lab program based on 80 percent wet lab and 20 percent dry lab. The lab floors have been configured to maximize future flexibility. The mechanical and electrical rooms, power and communication distribution systems, general and special exhaust risers, floor drains and service zones, have been established to allow for fit-out by future tenants.
Phase 1 began operations in 2005.<ref name="How did MaRS get started"/>
=== West Tower === West Tower (formerly known as Phase 2), designed by Bregman + Hamann Architects, constitutes a {{convert|780000|sqft|m2|adj=on}} addition to the MaRS centre in the form of a 20-story tower on the complex’s west wing. The tower was developed by [[Alexandria Real Estate Equities]].<ref name=":0" /> Construction began in late 2007, and was scheduled to be completed in spring 2010.<ref>[http://www.marsdd.com/News/Press-Releases/2007/Alexandria-20070626.html MaRS Selects Alexandria Real Estate Equities to Expand the MaRS Centre in the Discovery District of Toronto.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080705022315/http://www.marsdd.com/News/Press-Releases/2007/Alexandria-20070626.html |date=2008-07-05 }}. Accessed on: June 26, 2007.</ref> In November 2008, Phase 2 construction was put on hold due to the [[Late 2000s recession|economic downturn]].<ref>[http://www.financialpost.com/news/story.html?id=970255 Toronto's MaRS project a step too far. By Garry Marr, Financial Post Published: Tuesday, November 18, 2008] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090506053832/http://www.financialpost.com/news/story.html?id=970255 |date=May 6, 2009 }}</ref> [http://www.marsdd.com/news-insights/newsreleases/mars-centre-phase-2-set-for-completion-in-fall-2013-2/ Construction resumed] in July 2011, with a target completion date of Fall 2013.
In 2011, construction of Phase 2 restarted. Phase 2 construction was expected to be completed in September 2013.<ref>[http://www.marsdd.com/newsreleases/mars-centre-phase-2-set-for-completion-in-fall-2013-2/ MaRS Centre Phase 2 Set for Completion in Fall 2013]</ref> Phase 2 of the project was facing criticism because the [[Ontario Government|Government of Ontario]] provided a [[bailout]] for the organization which is facing difficulty leasing the floors. The [[Ontario Progressive Conservative Party]] was calling for a full accounting of MaRS Phase 2.<ref>{{cite web|author=Alex Bouitilier|title=Ontario Tories call for clarity on MaRS costs|url=https://www.thestar.com/news/queenspark/2014/05/30/ontario_tories_call_for_clarity_on_mars_costs.html|work=[[Toronto Star]]|publisher=TorStar Media|accessdate=9 December 2014}}</ref> By November 2016, 93% of the building had been leased, with the rest in negotiation.<ref name=":0">{{cite web|author=Shelley White|title=The story of the West Tower|url=https://magazine.marsdd.com/the-story-of-the-west-tower-3e130b165c4e#|work=[[Toronto Star]]|publisher=MaRS Discovery District|accessdate=25 January 2017}}</ref>
In 2016, [[IBM]] announced plans to join the finTech hub at MaRS. The hub has financial services companies, including CIBC, Manulife and Moneris.<ref>[http://business.financialpost.com/fp-tech-desk/ibm-to-be-first-tech-tenant-in-torontos-mars-fintech-hub-will-focus-on-cognitive-technologies "IBM to be first technology tenant in Toronto’s MaRS discovery district’s fintech hub"]. ''Financial Post'', Alexandra Posadzki, August 30, 2016</ref>
==Supporters== MaRS is supported, in part, by professional service organizations which offer their expertise at no cost through education and training, and advisory hours.
The current list of organizations include: {{columns-list|colwidth=30em| * AIC Limited * AstraZeneca Canada Inc * Baycrest Centre for Geriatric Care * Lawrence S. Bloomberg * Cancer Care Ontario * CIBC * Eli Lilly Canada Inc * John R. Evans * The Henry White Kinnear Foundation * Arthur S. Labatt * MDS Inc. * NPS Pharmaceuticals * St. Michael's Hospital * Peter Munk * RBC Financial Group * Joseph L. Rotman * Allan Slaight * Toronto Rehabilitation Institute * William P. Wilder * Government of Ontario * Government of Canada * City of Toronto * University of Toronto * Ryerson University }}
==Criticism== [[Image:MaRSAtrium.jpg|200 px|thumb|Inside the MaRS Centre atrium.]]
In April 2010, criticism of the $471,874 salary collected by MaRS CEO Ilse Treurnicht in 2008 was raised.<ref>{{cite news|author=Greg Boutin |title=Troubling Facts about MaRS Discovery District |url=http://www.growthtimes.com/2010/04/troubling-facts-about-mars-discovery-district-part-1-of-4/ |work=Growth Times |date=April 2010 |accessdate=September 27, 2010|subscription=yes}}</ref> It also criticized Liberal government-led funding, lack of accountability and rigor in measuring results, claims of public-private partnerships and the absence of visible minorities among MaRS's team of advisors.
On August 27, 2010, the [[National Post]] relayed some of these criticisms<ref>{{cite news|author=Adam McDowell |title=Discovering life at MaRS: Toronto’s premier innovation district |work=[[National Post]]|date=August 27, 2010 |url=http://www.nationalpost.com/Discovering+life+MaRS+Toronto+premier+innovation+district/3452631/story.html |accessdate=September 27, 2010}}</ref>
Renewed criticism was published in 2011, pointing in particular to the $100,000 increase in Treurnicht's salary, her $534,000 salary in 2010, and questioning the public and private funding of the Phase II expansion.<ref>{{cite news|author=Greg Boutin |title=CEO of MaRS got 22% raise (one month before Ontario wage freeze?), made $533K in 2010 |work=Growth Times |date=August 3, 2011|url=http://www.growthtimes.com/2011/08/ceo-of-mars-got-22-raise-one-month-before-ontario-wage-freeze-made-533k-in-2010|accessdate=August 5, 2011|subscription=yes}}</ref> The [[Toronto Sun]] published articles on the topic as well, questioning the high compensation levels at the charitable trust institution.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.torontosun.com/2011/08/02/salaries-increase-at-mars-discovery-district|author=Jonathan Jenkins |title=Salaries increase at MaRS Discovery District |work=[[Toronto Sun]] |date=August 2, 2011 |accessdate=August 5, 2011}}</ref>
== Initiatives and affiliations == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070702025915/http://www.torontodiscoverydistrict.ca/ The Toronto Discovery District] * [http://www.ccsip.org/ California-Canada Strategic Innovation Partnership] * [http://www.sigeneration.ca/ Social Innovation Generation (SiG)] * [http://remarkk.com/2007/02/18/creative-convergence-centres-hubs-within-the-cluster/ Creative Convergence Centres Project] * [http://www.marsdd.com/premiersummit/ Premier’s Summit Awards] * [http://www.stemcellnetwork.ca/ Canadian Stem Cell Network] * [http://www.stockholmsciencecity.com/en/ Stockholm Science City] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20090404040135/http://netchangeweek.ca/ Net Change Week]
