revision.text:
{{Infobox person | image = |birth_name = Manuel de Jesús Clouthier del Rincón | birth_date = {{birth date|1934|06|13}} | birth_place = [[Culiacán]], [[Sinaloa]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1989|10|01|1934|06|13}} | death_place = [[Culiacán]], [[Sinaloa]] |other_names = Maquío | spouse = Leticia Carrillo | children = [[Tatiana Clouthier Carrillo|Tatiana]], [[Manuel Clouthier Carrillo|Manuel]], Rebeca, Lorena, Leticia María, Eric, Juan Pablo, Lucía, Ricardo and Irene | party = [[National Action Party (Mexico)|National Action]] | alma_mater = [[Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education]] }}
'''Manuel de Jesús Clouthier del Rincón''' (b.June 13, 1934 – d.October 1, 1989)<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.memoriapoliticademexico.org/Biografias/CMJ34.html|title=Manuel Jesús Clouthier del Rincón|last=|first=|date=|website=Memoría Política de México|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 5, 2018}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/articulo/manuel-clouthier-carrillo/nacion/los-clouthier|title=Los Clouthier|last=|first=|date=April 20, 2018|work=El Universal|access-date=June 5, 2018|location=Mexico City}}</ref> was a Mexican agriculturalist, businessman and politician. His [[Mexican general election, 1988|1988 presidential campaign]] challenged the dominance of Mexico’s [[Institutional Revolutionary Party|PRI party]] in the nation’s politics, with rhetoric and protests before, during and after the elections. Although officially coming in third, he remained a prominent political force in Mexico until his death in a car accident a year after the elections. ==Life== Clouthier was born on June 13, 1934 in [[Culiacán]], [[Sinaloa]], Mexico to Manuel Clouther Martínez de Castro and María Cristina del Rincón Bernal.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> His family owned 30,000 hectares of land in the Culiacán Valley as the descendent of Jean Auguste Clouthier, a French-Canadian doctor who made his home there in 1850.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=|title=Chihuahua Journal; To Lay Waste a Dynasty: A 'Northern Barbarian'|last=Rohter|first=Larry|date=May 3, 1988|work=New York Times|access-date=|page=A4}}</ref>
He became known to friends and family, and later as a political figure by the nickname “Maquio” which he got during childhood.<ref name=":4">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1989-10-02/news/mn-400_1_car-crash|title=Charismatic Mexican Politician Manuel Clouthier Dies in Car Crash|last=Miller|first=Marjorie|date=October 2, 1989|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=June 5, 2018}}</ref>
He spent his early childhood in Culiacan, attending primary school at Colegio Cervantes. In 1942, his parents divorced and he moved with his mother and two brothers to [[Guadalajara]]. His mother remarried in Guadalajara, after which Manuel and his brother Marco Antonio were enrolled in the Instituto de Ciencias. Manuel was expelled from the school for bad behavior.<ref name=":0" />
In 1947, the boys’ father sent them to the United States to study middle school at the Brown Military Academy in Los Angeles. Clouthier left the school with the rank of first lieutenant. He then studied for a short time at the [[Black-Foxe Military Institute|Black Fox Military Institute]] in San Diego.<ref name=":0" />
He returned to Mexico in 1951 to attend high school at [[Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education, Monterrey|Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Studies in Monterrey,]] going study a bachelors in [[agricultural engineering]] at the same campus, graduating in 1957. In 1956 and 1957, he played [[defensive tackle]] and was president of the Student Association of the school.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=http://www.excelsior.com.mx/nacional/2014/10/01/984595|title=Tuvo Maquío meteórica y brillante carrera política|last=Galarza|first=Gerardo|date=October 1, 2014|work=El Excelsior|access-date=June 5, 2018|location=Mexico City}}</ref>
In 1959, he married Leticia Carrillo. The couple had eleven children, six daughters and five sons.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /> One of his sons committed suicide, prompting him to spend more time with his family.<ref name=":0" />
During his political career, Clouthier was heavy set, with white hair and beard. He was often described as fiery, with a blunt and aggressive style, and took pride in talking straight, often crudely.<ref name=":4" /> The newsweekly Proceso described him as “Businessman, Catholic, dynamic, vain, efficient, boastful, humorous, foulmouthed, aggressive, forthright, controversial…”<ref name=":5">{{Cite thesis|last=Ard|first=Michael James|title=Transforming great party politics: The National Action Party and its role in Mexico's democratic transition|date=2001|degree=PhD|publisher=University of Virginia|url=}}</ref> According to his son, “Maquío was raised in the social doctrine of the Catholic Church and believed that wealth created a social obligation. He believed in democracy, in the social economy of the market, respecting the dignity of the individual, in solidarity and in subsidiarity.”<ref name=":1" />
In his free time, he liked sports, singing, and playing poker and dominos.<ref name=":0" />
Clouthier died on October 1, 1989 in a car accident on the Mexico City-Nogales highway (KM158+100) in Culiacan, while on the way to a rally for a PAN candidate for mayor of [[Mazatlán]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> The car crashed with a truck loaded with fruit. Both occupants of Clouthier's car died instantly. The truck driver survived.<ref name=":2" /> There were rumors that it was not an accident, with several farmworkers reporting a helicopter in the area.<ref name=":0" /> The family asked for an investigation to clarify what happened in the accident.<ref>{{Cite news|url=|title=Demandan a PGR investigar muerte del 'Maquio'|last=Martinez|first=Fernando|date=December 28, 1995|work=El Norte|access-date=|location=Monterrey|page=1}}</ref> Thousands of people attended Clouthier’s funeral at the [[Culiacán Cathedral|Culiacán cathedral]] including [[Dionisio Garza Sada]], [[Mauricio Fernández Garza]], [[Concepción Guadalupe Garza]], [[Ingrid Fiehn]], [[Fernando Canales Clariond|Fernando Canales]], [[Raúl Monter]], [[Alberto Fernández Ruiloba]], [[Javier Livas]], [[Rafael Rangel Sostmann]], [[Porfirio Muñoz Ledo]], [[Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas]], [[Luis H. Álvarez|Luís H. Álvarez]], [[Elías Villegas]], [[Vicente Fox]] and [[Fernando Gutiérrez Barrios]]. Clouthier is buried at the Jardines del Humaya cemetery.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" />
His widow, Leticia Carrillo Cázarez, died in December of 2017 at age 84. Children, Rebeca, [[Tatiana Clouthier|Tatiana]] and [[Manuel Clouthier Carrillo|Manuel]] have since gone into politics, but not in his [[National Action Party (Mexico)|PAN party]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/nacion/politica/fallece-leticia-carrillo-viuda-de-manuel-j-clouthier-maquio|title=Fallece Leticia Carrillo, viuda de Manuel J. Clothier “Maquío”|last=Cabrera Martinez|first=Javier|date=December 15, 2017|work=El Universal|access-date=June 5, 2018|location=Mexico City}}</ref>
==Agro-industry career== After graduating from Monterrey Tech, he worked for a time with Paul Williams in [[Mexicali]]. He then returned to Culiacan, where his father gave him seventy hectares of land to farm. Here he grew tomatoes, chili peppers, cucumbers and rice. Clouthier was successful with this, increasing his land holdings to 270 hectares and starting fourteen businesses in [[Intensive farming|agroindustry]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":3" />
==Political career before presidential run== His success in business prompted his entry into politics. In 1969, he was elected president of the, Asociación de Agricultores del Río Culiacán. In 1971, he became the head of the Unión Nacional de Productores de Hortalizas. That same year, he founded the Comité de Caminos Vecinales and joined the Movimiento Familiar Cristiano.<ref name=":0" />
In 1971, he was nominated as a PRI candidate to become the municipal president of Culiacán, but another candidate was chosen to run. From then on, Clouthier shifted his focus to opposing the agrarian policies of then president [[Luis Echeverría|Luís Echeverría]], who expropriated lands during the last months of his term. Clouthier organized opposition businessmen, connected with other in similar situations in other states. Although he did not lose any of his lands, he suffered other repercussions and other pressures from local and federal governments.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":5" />
Between 1974 and 1978 he headed the Consejo Coordinador Empresarial de Sinaloa. Although unknown at the time, he was instrumental in the founding of the newspaper El Noroeste with Enrique Murillo and Jorge del Rincón. By 1978, he had national recognition as a business and political leader.<ref name=":0" />
In 1982, after the nationalization of the banks, he started the ''México a la libertad'' movement against authoritarianism, interventionism and increasing control of state of the economy.<ref name=":1" />
The bank situation also had the effect of turning him away from the ruling PRI party to an alternative.<ref name=":2" /> By 1983, he had joined the PAN party, as its ideology was closest to his own, but did not publicly announce the affiliation until 1984.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /> Clouthier was instrumental in bringing in new blood to PAN in the 1980s, recruiting owners of small and medium-sized businesses. He also brought in support from women, with PAN organizing groups called “Damas de Clouthier” (Clothier’s Ladies).<ref>{{Cite thesis|last=Shirk|first=David A.|title=Democratization and party -building: The growing pains of Mexico's National Action Party|date=2000|degree=PhD|publisher=University of California, San Diego|url=|doi=}}</ref>
In 1986, he was slated as the PAN candidate as governor of Sinaloa against [[Francisco Labastida|Francisco Labastido Ochoa]]. He lost but PAN did not accept the results.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> He introduced PAN to civil disobedience tactics, emboldened by events in the Philippines against the [[Ferdinand Marcos|Marcos]] regime, bringing in Philippine activists to teach peaceful civil disobedience. This made this party more radical than that of the past.<ref name=":5" /> These activities had repercussions in the press, with Clouthier and the PAN being branded as “the barbarians of the north”<ref name=":2" /> However, it became a point of pride with supports putting bumper stickers on their cars announcing themselves as northern barbarians.<ref name=":3" /> ==Presidential campaign== Clouthier launched his presidential candidacy in 1987 with PAN and was nominated by the party in November 1987, with 70% of the delegate vote.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":5" /> During his campaign, he toured Mexico with mobile home, with his wife and several of his children.<ref name=":4" /> Clouthier was an effective campaigner and his rallies drew large and enthusiastic crowds.<ref name=":5" /> As a stump speaker, he relied on a stock of earthy stories, puns, jokes, anecdotes and analogies to get his points across.<ref name=":3" /> Ending PRI’s dominance on the country’s politics became Clouthier’s main campaign theme, which also includes calls for greater personal freedom, less interference by the government in Mexico City and end to federal monopolies such as the printing of public school textbooks.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":5" /> He had appeal to traditional Catholics in the county. His candidacy was classified as be a new kind of right-wing population or new right for Mexico, distinguishing it from that of the [[Cristero War|Cristeros]] and Mexico anticommunists, with a broader message. It was not capitalist, more in line with the socialism of then [[West Germany]].<ref name=":5" />
After a successful interview with journalist Ricardo Rocha, the government-controlled media outlets blacked him out. In response, Clouthier organized a boycott of [[Jacobo Zabludovsky|Jacobo Zabludousky]]'s show “24 Horas” to protest the lack of opportunities for opposition candidates. He also protested the media lockout by holding silent rallies, in which he appeared with his mouth taped shut.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5" />
PRI announced on 7 July that its candidate had won the presidential election. At the Federal Electoral Commission a PAN official got a hold of a computer file with the real returns and when discovered, was evicted. The computer crashed and the final results were withheld for a week. Both Clouthier and PRD candidate Cuauhtémoc Cárdenas declared the election results illegitimate. Clouthier signed a document pledging to not accept the PRI victory, but neither would he acknowledge that Cárdenas probably won.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5" />
Clouthier and PAN affiliates took the streets in protest in Mexico City, including a rally to the [[Angel of Independence]] that drew about 20,000 people.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":5" /> Clouthier also started a public hunger strike as the same monument, not eating for 177 hours from the 15th to 22nd of December of 1988. After the end of the strike, a pro-government newspaper ran the headline “Maquio Ends Diet.”<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4" /> Salinas was confirmed as president but after weeks of vote recount, PRI recognized that PAN had won 101 seats in the [[Chamber of Deputies (Mexico)|Chamber of Deputies]], a record for the party.<ref name=":4" />
Clouthier remained a prominent figure even after his loss (placing third), until his death.<ref name=":4" /> In February 1989, Clouthier presented his “shadow cabinet” to monitor government actions in certain important areas. The cabinet proposed its own solutions to national issues. Clouthier was the coordinator of the cabinet.<ref name=":0" />
== References == <references />
==External links== *{{es icon}} [http://www.pan.org.mx/?P=22&ArtOrder=ReadArt&Article=26 National Action Party: Manuel J. Clouthier] *{{es icon}} [http://www.maquio.org.mx/ Manuel J. Cloutier "Maquío": Historical File]
{{s-start}} {{s-ppo}} {{succession box | before =[[Pablo Emilio Madero]] | title=[[National Action Party (Mexico)|PAN]] [[President of Mexico|presidential candidate]] | years=[[Mexican general election, 1988|1988]] (lost)| after = [[Diego Fernández de Cevallos]]}} {{s-end}}
{{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Cloutier, Manuel J}} [[Category:1934 births]] [[Category:1989 deaths]] [[Category:Mexican people of French descent]] [[Category:Mexican presidential candidates (1988)]] [[Category:National Action Party (Mexico) politicians]] [[Category:Mexican businesspeople]] [[Category:Mexican democracy activists]] [[Category:Mexican Roman Catholics]] [[Category:Politicians from Sinaloa]] [[Category:People from Culiacán]] [[Category:Monterrey Institute of Technology and Higher Education alumni]] [[Category:Road incident deaths in Mexico]]

'''Marco Piccinini''' (born 1952 in [[Rome]]) is a Monegasque sport personality, businessman, and politician. ==Personal== Picinnini's father Arnaldo was a pioneer in the Italian electronic industry. In the 1950s he founded an industrial group which included innovative brands such as VOXSON (TV, car radios, hi-fi etc.) and VIDEOCOLOR (color TV picture tubes and other hi-tech electronic components). At the end of the 1960s, due to Arnaldo's declining health, the family disposed of their interests in the various industrial activities and decided to move to Monaco where, after his father's death, Marco focused on his two main interests – finance and motor racing.[1] Marco studied architecture in Rome, where he also began his involvement in motor racing[2] by cooperating with a Formula 3 constructor and racing team called ‘‘De Sanctis’’. He also received training in the Techniques of International Negotiations at the Graduate Institute of International Studies in [[Geneva]]. In 1997 married Marie-Ahlem and they have a daughter. ==Institutional== * 2017, Senior Advisor to the Minister of State of the Principality of Monaco. * 2011-2012, Minister of Finance and Economy of the Principality of Monaco. In this capacity he focused particularly on: - restoring a balanced budget, generating a cash surplus in 2012;
- Introducing new legislations and process to ensure compliance of Monaco with modern standards in the field of international tax cooperation (OCED - Global Tax Forum) and anti-money laundering (Moneyval);
- reducing the risk profile of the Monaco National Reserve Fund while preserving its profitability. * 2010, he served as [[Monégasque Ambassador to China|Ambassador of Monaco to China]] and [[India-Monaco relations|India]]. === Professional career === * 2013, his advisory firm MPC provides consulting and other services in particular in the fields of luxury industry, Motor Sport and finance. * He has been Member of the Board of several companies including banks and listed groups. == Sport == Société Monégasque de Constructions Automobiles MP * 1974 - co-founded the first Monegasque racing car manufacturer - Société Monégasque de Constructions Automobiles MP - which produced a few Formula 3 single seaters. Ferrari (https://web.archive.org/web/20081208000000/http://www.ferrariworld.com/FWorld/fw/index.jsp) * 1977 - appointed by [[Enzo Ferrari]] as his representative for Formula 1 matters and shortly afterward appointed as the ‘‘Direttore Sportivo’’ of the Ferrari Team.[3] * 1978-1988, Motor Sport Director of Ferrari and Team Principal of the Formula 1 Team. In this capacity he was one of the architects of the ‘‘Concorde Agreement’’, the charter governing regulatory as well as financial aspects of the Formula 1 World Championship. * From 1983 until 2016, Member of the Board of Directors of Ferrari SpA. CSAI - Commissione Sportiva Automobilistica Italiana (http://www.csai.aci.it/csai/) * 1993-1994, President of CSAI, the Italian Motor Sport Federation and elected in 1994 as a Vice President of FIA, the international Motor Sport Governing Body. Prada Challenge for America’s Cup * 1997-2000, Executive Deputy Chairman and Challenge Representative of the PRADA Team during the America’s Cup XXX (Auckland 2000). [[Luna Rossa Challenge|Luna Rossa]] won the Louis Vuitton Cup and became the finalist against Team New Zealand. * Member of the Board of ACCA (America’s Cup Challengers Association); * Chairman of the marketing Committee of ACCA; * Executive Chairman of the Challenger of Record Management for America’s Cup XXXI (i.e. the challengers association), the organiser of the Challenger Selection Series, also known as the Louis Vuitton Cup. FOA – Formula One Administration * 1998-99, Deputy CEO of FOA and FOM - Formula One Management (commercial rights holders for the Formula 1 World Championship). FIA – Fédération Internationale de l’Automobile (http://www.fia.com/en-{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} GB/Pages/HomePage.aspx) * 1998-2008 Deputy President of FIA, chaired the World Motor Sport Council, the executive body which regulates all motor sport disciplines worldwide. Piccinini was serving out his third term as Deputy President but left his post a year early to focus on other professional commitments.[4] == Monaco Sporting Associations == * 1981-2010 member of the Board of Directors of '''[http://www.acm.mc/ Automobile Club de Monaco)]''', the organiser of the Monaco Grand Prix and Monte-Carlo Rally. * 1999-2010, member of the Executive Committee of the '''[http://www.yacht-club-monaco.mc/ Yacht Club de Monaco]''', supervising international relations and marketing activities. Also a member of the Constitution Committee of '''[http://www.sailing.org/ ISAF - International Sailing Federation]'''. * 1999-2010, member of the Committee of '''[http://www.mccc.mc/ MCCC – Monte-Carlo Country Club]''' - the organiser of the Tennis Masters Series Monte Carlo – dealing in particular with marketing and media rights negotiations concerning the Tournament, one of the ATP Super 9 Events. * 2003-2009, member of the Board of Directors of '''[https://web.archive.org/web/20080509154430/http://www.asm-fc.com/ AS Monaco Football Club]''', several times winner of the French Premier League and finalist of the 2004 UEFA Champion’s League. == Finance == '''Société de Crédit et de Banque de Monaco (Socrédit)''' * 1975–1989, member of the Board of Directors of ''Société de Crédit et de Banque de Monaco (Socrédit)'', then one of the most active Monegasque banks and the subsidiary of an international financial group. '''Société d'Etudes de Participations et de Courtages (SEPAC)''' * 1978-2010, member of the Board of Directors of SEPAC, a property and real estate management company. '''[http://www.creditmobilierdemonaco.com/ Crédit Mobilier de Monaco (CMM)]''' * 1981-2010, member of the Board of Directors of Crédit Mobilier de Monaco. '''[http://www.cmb.mc/index_fr.php/ Compagnie Monégasque de Banque (Monaco)]''' * 2006-2010, member of the Board of Directors of Compagnie Monégasque de Banque: the international private banking subsidiary of [[Mediobanca]]. '''[http://www.finter.ch/site/index.cfm/id_art/16344 Finter Bank Zurich]''' * From 1989 until 2015, member of the Board of Directors of this medium size Swiss banking group, specialized in private banking and asset/funds management. '''[http://en.montecarloresort.com/ SBM - Société des Bains de Mer à Monaco]''' * From 1998 until 2009, member of the Board of Directors of SBM, the largest Monegasque company, listed on the Paris stock exchange. SBM is the main resort and luxury hotel operator of the Principality of Monaco, including the Hotel de Paris, Hotel Hermitage, Les Casinos de Monte-Carlo, the Monte-Carlo Sporting Club etc. Also served as chairman of the Human Resources Committee of the Board. '''[http://www.poltronafrau.it/ Poltrona Frau SpA]''' * From 2006 until 2010, a member of the Board of Directors of the Group, one of the world’s leading producers of luxury furnishing under three principal brands, Poltrona Frau, Cassina, Cappellini. '''Charme Capital Partners SGR''' * From 2007 until 2016, independent Director of Charme Partners SGR, an international Private Equity management company. '''[https://web.archive.org/web/20130703142004/http://www.italcementigroup.com/ENG/ Italcementi SpA]''' * From 1992 until 2013, a member of the Board of Directors of this group, one of the leading worldwide construction materials producer. '''Church’s Shoes Ltd''' * From 2006 until 2014, a member of the Board of Directors of Church’s Shoes Ltd., the English luxury shoes maker, member of the PRADA Group.{{cite web|url=http://www.church-footwear.com/|title=Church's footwear|work=Church's footwear|accessdate=11 June 2015}} '''ABR Management''' * Since 2013, member of the Board of Directors of ABR Management.{{cite web|url=http://www.abr-m.ru/en/|title=ABR MANAGEMENT - Main|work=abr-m.ru|accessdate=11 June 2015}} ABR Management is the holding company in particular for [https://web.archive.org/web/20130618200714/http://web.abr.ru/en/ Bank of Rossiya], [[Sogaz|Sogaz Insurance Group]] and National Media Group.{{cite web|url=http://www.nm-g.ru/|title=National Media Group|work=nm-g.ru|accessdate=11 June 2015}} == Other positions == Piccinini currently serves also as a member of :{{cite web|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/businessweek/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=8324612&ticker=PFG:IM&previousCapId=874249&previousTitle=L'OREAL|title=List of Public Companies Worldwide, Letter - Businessweek - Businessweek|work=Businessweek.com|accessdate=11 June 2015}} * the Supervisory Board of Nice Airport. * the Board of Trustees of Villa Nazareth Foundation (the Vatican): an educational institution active since 1946. * the Board of Trustees International Theological Institute, Trumau, Austria:{{cite web|url=http://www.iti.ac.at|title=International Theological Institute: Home|work=iti.ac.at|accessdate=11 June 2015}} a Catholic theological faculty with degrees granted by the Holy See. == References == {{DEFAULTSORT:Piccinini, Marco}} [[Category:1952 births]] [[Category:Monegasque businesspeople]] [[Category:Monegasque people of Italian descent]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Ferrari people]] [[Category:Formula One people]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Monaco to China]] [[Category:Ambassadors of Monaco to India]] [[Category:Graduate Institute of International and Development Studies alumni]] [[Category:Government ministers of Monaco]]

{{EngvarB|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Melvin Wong Hwang Chee | image = Melvin Wong Hwang Chee.jpg | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Melvin Wong Hwang Chee | birth_date = {{birth date and age|df=yes|1978|07|30}} | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|df=yes|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = Malaysian | other_names = | occupation = Entrepreneur, speaker, businessman | years_active = 2005–present | known_for = [[FanXT]] | notable_works = }}
'''Melvin Wong Hwang Chee''' (born 30 July 1978) is a Malaysian entrepreneur, speaker and businessman. He was the founder of [[FanXT]], a [[fantasy sport]]s platforms for [[The Football Association]], [[MotoGP]] and [[Formula One]].<ref>[https://www.digitalnewsasia.com/sizzle-fizzle/justmobileincs-wong-makes-a-pivot-to-fantasy-sports?page=0%2C0 Melvin Wong Hwang Chee makes a pivot to fantasy sports] Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref>
== Career == Melvin was born on 30 July 1978, in [[Kuching]], [[Sarawak]]. He started his company ''Just Mobile'' in 2005 which expanded into a fantasy sports platform known as [[FanXT]].<ref>[http://www.dealstreetasia.com/stories/malaysia-grand-perfecta-acquires-just-mobile-for-undisclosed-amount-to-enter-us-market-27609/ Just Mobile founder and chief executive officer Melvin Wong] Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref> In 2016, Grand Perfecta Inc., a [[Tokyo]] based company, acquired FanXT via its U.S subsidiary, Sports Perfecta Inc.<ref>[http://finance.yahoo.com/news/grand-perfecta-inc-acquires-fanxt-060500692.html Grand Perfecta, Inc., Acquires FanXT to Expand Into Fantasy Sports Market] ''[[Yahoo Finance]]'' Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref>
In 2012, Melvin represented his country at [[Global Entrepreneurship Week]], organised by [[United States Department of State]], which was held at [[The White House]] in [[Washington DC]]. In 2013, Melvin was a speaker at science, technology and entrepreneurship event together with [[Assistant Secretary of State for Oceans and International Environmental and Scientific Affairs]], [[Kerri-Ann Jones]] at [[Universiti Teknologi MARA System]] in Malaysia. He was also a speaker at [[Global Entrepreneurship Program|The Global Entrepreneurship Summit]] which was officiated by [[President Obama]] and was held in 2013.<ref>[http://thesbec.org/mentors/melvin-wong/ Country representative in Global Entrepreneurship Week event in the U.S White House in 2012] Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref>
Melvin was the winner of ''MyEG Make The Pitch Season 2'', a business [[reality show]] that was aired on [[8TV (Malaysia)]] in 2012. He won a sum of [[MYR]] 1 million investment money from MyEG which he later turned down.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4oAk830llTc&feature=c4-overview&list=UUuPCKwwr2rbEjDVQ0P7lWjw MyEG Make The Pitch, a reality show showcasing Malaysian entrepreneurs pitching their innovative ideas to a group of potential investors in order to gain monetary investment airing on 8TV] Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref> He was also among the semi-finalists at ''Startup Asia'' business TV reality show aired on [[Channel News Asia]] in 2014.<ref>[http://live.utusan.com.my/Event/Laporan_Langsung_Wartawan_Utusan_Online_2014/128731009 Melvin Wong Hwang yang mecipta Perisian Applikasi Fantasy Football Untuk Sistem Android Google dan Sistem Opera] Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref>
Melvin has won several local and international awards including the [[TiE]]’s ''All-Asia Business Plan Competition'' in 2012 and Malaysia's ''National Intellectual Property Award'', organised by MyIPO in 2014.<ref>[https://www.digitalnewsasia.com/sizzle-fizzle/tie--malaysia-out-to-help-entrepreneurs-keeps-it-casual Melvin Wong, Eddie Lim and Hassanal Burhanuddin, presented a winning business plan on a fantasy online game website] Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref><ref>[http://www.theborneopost.com/2014/10/03/wipo-lauds-malaysian-ip-management/ World Intellectual Property Organisation praises Malaysian IP management] ''[[The Borneo Post]]'' Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref> Melvin's [[FanXT]] was a finalist in ''The Football Business Awards 2014'' together with [[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg Sports]], [[FIFA]] and [[Sky Deutschland]].<ref>[https://integrity.sportradar.com/news-archive/news/2014/09/sportradar-security-services-shortlisted-in-two-categories-at-football-business-awards/ Sportradar Security Services shortlisted in two categories at Football Business Awards] Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref><ref>[http://www.it-sideways.com/2014/12/brace-of-respected-awards-for-fanxt.html Brace of Respected Awards for FanXT] Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref><ref>[http://www.nextupasia.com/malaysias-fanxt-waved-high-jalur-gemilang-at-asia-level-business-competition-in-india/Malaysia’s FanXT waved high Jalur Gemilang at Asia Level Business Competition in India] Retrieved 24 January 2017</ref> Currently, Melvin is a mentor with The South Bay Entrepreneurial Center in [[California]].<ref>[http://thesbec.org/mentors/melvin-wong/ The South Bay Entrepreneurial Center] Retrieved 25 January 2017</ref>
== Awards == * ''National Intellectual Property Awards'' - Malaysia - (2014) * ''[[Global Innovation through Science and Technology initiative|GIST]]'' - U.S - (2013) * ''[[TiE]] Global All-Asia Business Competition'' - India - (2012) * ''MSC Asia Pacific ICT Awards (APICTA)'' - Malaysia - (2011) * ''MIPTV Finalist for Content 360 Competition - MIPTV'' - France - (2010) * ''InnOvation Malaysia Awards - Malaysia'' - (2009) * ''Mobile Monday Global Summit Peer Awards'' - Malaysia - (2008) * ''MSC Mobile Content Competition'' - Malaysia - (2006)
== References == {{reflist|2}}

{{dablink|"Anastasijevic" redirects here, for people bearing the surname Anastasijević, see [[Anastasijević]].}} {{Infobox Officeholder | honorific_prefix = | name = Miša Anastasijević | honorific_suffix = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | image = Kapetan Miša Anastasijević2.jpg | image_size = | caption = Bust of Miša Anastasijević |office = 1st [[President of the National Assembly of Serbia]] |term_start = 30 November 1858 |term_end = 31 January 1859 |monarch = [[Alexander Karađorđević, Prince of Serbia|Aleksandar Karađorđević]]
[[Miloš Obrenović I]] |predecessor1 = Position established |successor1 = [[Živko Karabiberović]] | birth_name = Mihailo Anastasijević | birth_date = {{Birth date|1803|02|24}} | birth_place = [[Donji Milanovac|Poreč]], [[Pashaluk of Belgrade]], [[Ottoman Empire]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1885|01|27|1803|02|24}} | death_place = [[Bucharest]], [[Kingdom of Romania]] | death_cause = | resting_place = [[Clejani]] | resting_place_coordinates = | monuments = Bust in [[Belgrade]] | residence = | nationality = {{flagicon|Serbia|civil}} [[Principality of Serbia|Serbian]] | other_names = Miša | ethnicity = [[Serbs|Serb]] | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = | occupation = | years_active = | employer = | organization = | agent = | known_for = 2nd richest person in Serbia
[[Captain Miša's Mansion]] | notable_works = | style = | influences = | influenced = | home_town = | salary = | net_worth = | height = | weight = | television = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = | movement = | opponents = | boards = | religion = [[Serbian Orthodox Church|Serbian Orthodoxy]] | denomination = | spouse = Hristina Urošević | children = Sara
Ružica
Jelena
Anka
Persida | parents = Anastas
Ruža | relatives = | awards = | module = {{Infobox military person|embed=yes | rank = Captain | commands = [[Danube]] | relations = [[Miloš Obrenović I, Prince of Serbia]] }} | module2 = | footnotes = | box_width = }} '''Mihailo "Miša" Anastasijević''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Миша Анастасијевић}}; February 24, 1803 – January 27, 1885) was the second richest man in [[Serbia]] in the 19th century, through his successful salt export from [[Wallachia]] and [[Moldavia]] and business partnership with the richest, [[Miloš Obrenović I, Prince of Serbia]]. He was also the ''Captain of Danube'', and acquired significant benefits from Prince Miloš. He was the first public benefactor in [[Serbia]] and organizer of various balls for the [[Belgrade]] [[bourgeoisie]]. ==Life== He was born in Poreč, modern [[Donji Milanovac]], Serbia. His father, Anastas, was a landowner and petty businessman. His mother, Ruža, was a homemaker. His stepmother Milja took care of him after his father's death. Miša and Milja twice crossed the Danube into Austria during the [[First Serbian Uprising]] of the [[Serbian Revolution]]. At 11 years, he was a teacher in his hometown, because he could read and write. He was a business partner of [[Miloš Obrenović I, Prince of Serbia]], notably the richest. At the age of thirty he received the military title of Danube Captain and at the same time has acquired significant commercial benefits from Prince Miloš. His company soon gained control over salt exports from [[Wallachia]] and [[Moldavia]]. At the top of his career, Miša Anastasijević employed circa 10,000 workers and had a fleet of 80 ships. He was the first public benefactor in [[Serbia]] and organizer of various balls for the [[Belgrade]] [[bourgeoisie]]. Anastasijević was called the “Prince of Danube” or “Danube [[Rothschild]]” for his wealth and business skills. Captain Miša Anastasijević married his daughter to a Prince from the ruling [[Karađorđević]] family and built the most impressive building in the city ([[Captain Miša’s Mansion]]), which was supposed to be the new court, although this plan failed. The building hosted almost every important educational and cultural institutions of the [[Principality of Serbia]] - Ministry of Education, the [[University of Belgrade#History|Belgrade Higher School]], which became the [[University of Belgrade]], [[First Belgrade Gymnasium]], [[National Museum of Serbia|National Museum]], Art Gallery and Library. Occasionally, its gala hall has been used for the meetings of the [[National Assembly of Serbia|National Assembly]] (1864–1875) and Senate (1901–1903). Today, there is the Rectorate of the [[University of Belgrade]]. == See also == *[[Award of Captain Miša Anastasijević]], annual award given to the best companies of Serbia *[[Captain Miša's Mansion]] *[[University of Belgrade]] *[[Luka Ćelović]] *[[Đorđe Vajfert]] *[[Nikola Spasić]] == External links == * [http://www.batakovic.com/belgrade19thcent.html D. Bataković, ''The Serbian revolution: Nation-Building and Modernization'', 2005] * [http://web.mit.edu/most/www/ser/Belgrade/captain.html Belgrade - Captain Miša's Building] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Anastasijevic, Misa}} [[Category:19th-century Serbian nobility]] [[Category:Serbian businesspeople]] [[Category:Serbian military leaders]] [[Category:1803 births]] [[Category:1885 deaths]] [[Category:Serbian philanthropists]]

{{use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox Prime Minister | image = | name = Mohammed Karim Lamrani | order = 7th [[Prime Minister of Morocco]] | monarch = [[Hassan II of Morocco|Hassan II]] | deputy = | term_start = 11 August 1992 | term_end = 25 May 1994 | predecessor = [[Azzeddine Laraki]] | successor = [[Abdellatif Filali]] | term_start2 = 30 November 1983 | term_end2 = 30 September 1986 | predecessor2 = [[Maati Bouabid]] | successor2 = [[Azzeddine Laraki]] | term_start3 = 6 August 1971 | term_end3 = 2 November 1972 | predecessor3 = [[Ahmed Laraki]] | successor3 = [[Ahmed Osman (politician)|Ahmed Osman]] | birth_date = {{birth date|1919|5|1|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Fes, Morocco|Fes]], Morocco | death_date = {{dda|2018|9|20|1919|5|1|df=y}} | death_place = [[Casablanca]] | party = [[Independent politician|Independent]] | religion = }}
'''Mohammed Karim Lamrani''' ({{lang-ar|محمد كريم العمراني}}; 1 May 1919 – 20 September 2018)<ref>https://lematin.ma/express/2018/mohamed-karim-lamrani-n-plus/301073.html</ref> was a Moroccan politician who was the [[Prime Minister]] of [[Morocco]] for three separate terms.
==Early life== Lamrani was born in [[Fes, Morocco|Fes]] on 1 May 1919.<ref name="Birth">[https://books.google.com/books?id=364bAQAAMAAJ&q=Mohammed+Karim+Lamrani+1919&dq=Mohammed+Karim+Lamrani+1919&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiw3oKV8ovUAhWhC5oKHb9KAMYQ6AEILjAE Political Handbook and Atlas of the World]</ref>
==Career== Lamrani served as a prime minister three times: from 6 August 1971 to 2 November 1972, then from 30 November 1983 and 30 September 1986 and lastly from 11 August 1992 to 25 May 1994.<ref name=Embassy>{{cite web|url=http://www.moroccoembassyin.org/government.html|title=Embassy of the Kingdom of Morocco: Government|accessdate=18 April 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130420094906/http://www.moroccoembassyin.org/government.html|archivedate=20 April 2013|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The last government he led was a caretaker government, replacing [[Azeddine Laraki]].<ref name=tdgaz>{{cite news|title=Caretaker government named in Morocco|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=PMBKAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vukMAAAAIBAJ&pg=2354,3038098&dq=mohammed+karim+lamrani&hl=en|accessdate=22 December 2012|newspaper=The Daily Gazette|date=12 August 1992|location=Rabat}}</ref> Lamrani also owned a [[phosphate]] company and served as an economic advisor to the Moroccan governments.<ref name=tdgaz/>
==Business== Lamrani was also a businessperson in Morocco. He created a holding (Groupe Safari), which is now run by his daughter Saida.<ref name=tq>{{cite news|title=Les cinq futures fortunes du Maroc à suivre selon Forbes|url=http://www.telquel-online.com/content/les-cinq-futures-fortunes-du-maroc-à-suivre-selon-forbes|accessdate=15 May 2014|newspaper=[[Telquel]]|date=15 May 2014}}</ref> The holding has many investments, in particular, it holds stakes in [[Crédit du Maroc]], Socodam Davum, and SMEIA, the exclusive dealer of [[BMW]] and [[Land Rover]] in Morocco.<ref name=tq/>
==Death== Lamrani died on 20 September 2018 at the age of 99 of natural causes.<ref>https://www.medias24.com/MAROC/Les-plus-de-Medias-24/185937-Deces-de-Mohamed-Karim-Lamrani.html</ref><ref>http://www.mapnews.ma/en/top-news/general/former-prime-minister-mohamed-karim-lamrani-passes-away</ref>
== References == <references/>
