{{advert|date=August 2018}} {{Infobox person | name = Paige Mycoskie | image = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1980|2|26}} | residence = Malibu, California | nationality = American | alma_mater = Arizona State University | occupation = Owner and Founder of Aviator Nation | television = The Amazing Race Season 2 | relatives = Blake Mycoskie (Brother) Tyler Mycoskie (Brother) | awards = GQ’s Menswear Designer of the Year, 2013, LA Business Journal “Top Bosses Under 30” 2007 | website = http://www.aviatornation.com, http://www.aviatornation.com/blogs/paigemycoskie-blog }}
Paige Mycoskie<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|url=https://www.aviatornation.com/blogs/news/112322887-malibu-magazine-paige-mycoskie-feature|title=MALIBU MAGAZINE : PAIGE MYCOSKIE FEATURE|last=Nation|first=Aviator|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref> (born February 26, 1980) is an American artist, fashion designer, business owner, and entrepreneur, best known as the founder and owner of the [[California]]-made 70s-inspired contemporary lifestyle and casual wear brand and retail chain, [[Aviator Nation]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aviatornation.com/blogs/news/112322887-malibu-%20magazine-paige-%20%20mycoskie-feature|title=MALIBU MAGAZINE : PAIGE MYCOSKIE FEATURE|last=Nation|first=Aviator|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref> She is the sister of [[Blake Mycoskie]], founder and Chief Shoe Giver of [[Toms Shoes]]. In 2013, Mycoskie was named [[GQ|GQ’s Menswear Designer of the Year]] <ref name="auto"/><ref name="auto1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.gq.com/story/announcing-the-2013-gq-best-new-menswear-designers-in-america|title=Announcing the 2013 GQ Best New Menswear Designers in America|last=Sebra|first=Matt|date=2013-03-14|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref> and in 2007 was named one of [[Los Angeles Business Journal|LA Business Journal’s “Top Bosses Under 30”.]]
==Early life and education== Mycoskie was born in [[Arlington, Texas]] to Pam Mycoskie, an author and Mike Mycoskie, an orthopedic surgeon. She has two siblings: younger brother Tyler Mycoskie and older brother [[Blake Mycoskie]], founder and Chief Shoe Giver of [[Toms Shoes]]. She attended Arlington Martin High School where she was recognized as a state Volleyball champion. Excelling in sports, she was also on the Arizona State University Water Ski Team while attending ASU’s Walter Cronkite School of Journalism. An avid athlete, she still enjoys surfing; scuba diving; water skiing; and snowboarding.
Complimenting her lifelong love of athletics is her infinite passion for music, fashion, and art, most notably the sounds and casual wear made popular through the 60s and 70s [[counterculture]] era. Her paternal grandmother Hazel Mycoskie was a master seamstress and owned her own retail store specializing in denim fashions in the 70s, and would inspire Mycoskie to design, sketch, and produce garments from scratch.
Mycoskie spent her teenage years in Arlington on the hunt for 70s<ref name="auto2">{{Cite web|url=http://hoodline.com/2016/01/with-clothes-concerts-aviator-nation-makes-a-home-in-the-haight|title=With Clothes & Concerts, Aviator Nation Makes A Home In The Haight {{!}} Hoodline|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref> vintage tees and hoodies and attending concerts at Starplex, the nearby amphitheatre. She particularly is inspired by the history and the phenomena created by music and art festivals. Mycoskie cites [[Woodstock]] as a major influence in both her work and her personal life as the festival best encapsulates music’s power of connectivity, its ability to reveal our humanity, creativity, and personal expression.
== Amazing Race == Mycoskie and her brother Blake auditioned for CBS’ [[Survivor (U.S. TV series)|Survivor]] in 2001, independently sending in their applications. They both made it to final interviews. Realizing they were siblings, executives at CBS offered to cast both of them for season two of [[The Amazing Race]]. They agreed to that opportunity preferring to compete as a team. They finished in third place, missing the million dollar prize by four minutes.
== Career == In 2001 Mycoskie moved to [[Southern California]]<ref name="auto2"/> for her first internship at Shape Magazine. She soon shifted focus to freelance photography, video, graphic design, and branding. Opportunities for work in these fields were ideal for her adventurous and active lifestyle. She steadily developed successful campaigns in branding and commercials, and created the TOMS iconic logo for her brother’s company [[Toms Shoes|TOMS Shoes]]. She became a buyer’s assistant at ZJ Boarding House in Venice, CA where her love for clothing was reignited, dedicated to honoring the 70s casual wear style, look, and feel. She realized that the laid-back lifestyle of beach, surf, and sand provided the pivotal outlet for her to channel her life passions collectively. She wanted to create a brand that fostered athletics, adventure, creativity, music, and clothing all in one.
Discovering that vintage clothing was harder to find, Mycoskie decided to create her own clothes, sewing, dying, and designing herself. Debuting with a white hoodie with rainbow stripes in the hood, known as the brand’s “Signature Hoodie”, [[Aviator Nation]] was in business. The California [[surf culture]] is evident in all her pieces designing clothing, accessories, and surfboards.
== Aviator Nation == Mycoskie established Aviator Nation in Venice, CA in 2006. Gravitating towards clothing that suit her active lifestyle, Aviator Nation is a complete contemporary casual wear lifestyle brand, selling T-shirts, hoodies, sweatpants, tanks, outerwear, and hats to name a few. Mycoskie remains true to her inspired era, studying vintage fabrics, the process of fiber weaving, inks, and dye treatments popular in the 70s. Production of garments employ hand stitching and hand drawn graphics, ensuring originality, a vintage essence, and a worn-in feel.
Aviator Nation has a main focus in connecting fashion with music festivals, raising funds for philanthropies, and generating a greater awareness of our collective consciousness. The brand works with [[Global Citizen Festival]] by creating festival merchandise with proceeds aiding in the festival’s ongoing campaign to end poverty. The brand also has partnerships with [[Austin City Limits Music Festival]];<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aviatornation.com/blogs/news/114285127-behind-the-scenes-with-aviator-nation-at-austin-city-limits-2014|title=BEHIND THE SCENES with Aviator Nation at Austin City Limits 2014|last=Nation|first=Aviator|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://store.aclfestival.com/collections/aviator-nation-for-acl-festival|title=Aviator Nation for ACL Festival - ACL Music Festival|website=store.aclfestival.com|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/may/19/image/la-ig-paige-mycoskie-20130519|title=Aviator Nation's founder always looks on the bright side|last=Moore|first=Booth|date=2013-05-19|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref> [[Music festival|Lollapalooza Music Festival]]; and with [[John Mayer]]’s<ref name="auto1"/><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://johnmayer.shop.musictoday.com/product/JMCT345/jm-x-aviator-nation-rugby-t-shirt|title=JM x Aviator Nation Rugby T-shirt|website=johnmayer.shop.musictoday.com|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefashionisto.com/gap-x-gq-2013-best-new-designers-collection-highlights/|title=Gap x GQ 2013 Best New Designers Collection Highlights|date=2013-09-24|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2013/sep/23/news/la-ar-gap-x-gq-best-new-menswear-designers-collection-20130923|title=Gap x GQ Best New Menswear Designers collection drops Tuesday|last=Tschorn|first=Adam|date=2013-09-23|newspaper=Los Angeles Times|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref> previous concert tours.
== Career Highlights == In 2013, Mycoskie was named GQ’s Menswear Designer of the Year and in 2008 was named one of [[Los Angeles Business Journal|LA Business Journal’s]] “Top Bosses Under 30”.
Mycoskie and Aviator Nation have been featured in: LA Times, NY Times, GQ, Vogue, Elle, Harpers Bazaar, Nylon, Self, Fitness, Shape, Travel and Leisure, Malibu Magazine, LA Business journal, WWD, California Apparel News, People, Time, Details, Rolling Stone, Glamour, Foam, Entertainment Weekly, Juxtapoz, Cosmo, Seventeen, Us Weekly, Bloomberg Report, Antenna, Life &amp; Style, Safari
== Personal life == Mycoskie is an avid surfer/musician and loves the [[Hawaiian Islands]]. Passions for surfing, music, and her Southern California lifestyle are all very present in her signature designs. Music fuels much of her artistry, noting [[Fleetwood Mac]], [[The Beach Boys]], and [[Eagles (band)|The Eagles]] as sound favorites. Aviator Nation’s prints include drawings from Mycoskie’s earliest sketches, and she still hand draws some of the icons found on her clothing from the signature lightning bolts to psychedelic maidens. The use of rainbows and bright colors found in Aviator Nation clothing that has now become the brand’s niche, comes from her mother Pam’s preference of decorating and dressing Mycoskie in bold colors and rainbows prints.
Mycoskie is extremely hands-on with every aspect of her brand. Whether it be painting the inside of one of her flagship stores, drawing each graphic by hand, or communicating face to face with her customers, she is very much involved in each element of the company. She has been referred to as “A Jill-of- all-trades” and described as having “a lively dream-catcher spirit”. Regular visits to the [[Los Angeles]]-based factory are part of her weekly routine. Her goal is to have wearers and supporters feel like rock stars when sporting her brand, a full reflection of her own lifestyle.
Mycoskie is a philanthropist and has done projects and events for a variety of non-profits including Charity Water; Surf Aid; Heal the Bay; Surfer’s Healing; and Global Citizen.
She resides in [[Malibu, California]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.travelandleisure.com/articles/malibu-california-beach-getaway|title=Malibu: California Beach Getaway|access-date=2016-07-13}}</ref>

'''PerForm''' and '''PerForm PRO''' were electronic form programs, initially designed to work under [[Graphics Environment Manager|GEM]] in [[DOS]]. Later versions were designed to work in [[Windows 3.1]], at which point it was succeeded by [[FormFlow]].
The initial version of PerForm was created in 1988 and was the first product released by [[Canada|Canadian]] software firm [[Delrina]], which became best known for its later fax software program, [[WinFax]]. Chief Technical Officer [[Bert Amato]] and President of the company [[Mark Skapinker]] came up with the idea for the product while working as consultants that what their clients wanted was a way to fill in forms electronically, rather than an easier way to create paper-based forms from a computer.<ref name="Softwarriors p34">{{Cite journal | last = Walmsley | first = Ann | title = Attack of the Softwarriors | journal = Report on Business Magazine | page = 34 | date = March 1994 }}</ref> The program consisted of two parts: a form design module which gave users a graphical user interface for creating and arranging form elements, using tools largely familiar to those using desktop publishing or paint programs of the era, and a separate form filling program which would display the resulting form that the user could then fill in<ref name="Zisman">{{cite web |url= http://www.zisman.ca/Articles/1991-92/Input_May92.html |title= PerForm Pro |last= Zisman |first= Alan |date= May 1992 |website= Alan Zisman on Technology |publisher= INPUT |access-date= November 15, 2017}}</ref>. Those entering information into the forms could not change or alter the forms; they were limited to adding information in the various form fields on screen. Some of the potential uses of the program included being able to create invoices, payment records, personnel and payroll forms, and just about any other standardized form that may have been required.<ref name="Zisman">{{cite web |url= http://www.zisman.ca/Articles/1991-92/Input_May92.html |title= PerForm Pro |last= Zisman |first= Alan |date= May 1992 |website= Alan Zisman on Technology |publisher= INPUT |access-date= November 15, 2017}}</ref> Later versions of the program had some integration with Delrina's popular [[WinFax]] program, enabling users to [[fax]] material to clients based on information entered into PerForm.<ref name="Heck">{{cite web |url= https://books.google.ca/books?id=zDoEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA104 |title= PerForm, BizForms templates make filling in, filing forms a breeze |last= Heck |first= Mike |date= May 1995 |website= Google Books |publisher= InfoWorld |access-date= November 15, 2017}}</ref>
There was significant and long-term uptake of electronic forms products within governmental agencies both in Canada<ref name="TransportCanada">{{cite web|url=http://www.tc.gc.ca/gol/environment.htm |title="TRANSPORT CANADA'S IM/IT ENVIRONMENT 2006/2007", with a contemporary reference to the use of Delrina FormFlow |accessdate=2007-09-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070902012852/http://www.tc.gc.ca/gol/environment.htm |archivedate=2007-09-02 |df= }}</ref> and the United States,<ref name="USOffice">{{cite web | title = Office of Personnel Management Electronic Forms, FormFlow Versions of Standard Forms, July 14, 2000 | url= http://www.opm.gov/forms/html/ff_sf.htm | accessdate = August 24, 2009 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070331223006/http://www.opm.gov/forms/html/ff_sf.htm |archivedate = March 31, 2007}}</ref> the latter spurred on in particular by the requirements of the [[Paperwork Reduction Act]] to reduce the total amount of paperwork handled by the United States government.<ref name="Asbrand">{{Cite journal | last = Asbrand | first = Deborah | title = Forms automation needs brains | journal = InfoWorld | page = 79 | date = October 10, 1994 }}</ref> One of the firm's early major software deals included a multi-year agreement to sell PerForm to the U.S. Navy in 1990.<ref name="Softwarriors p34"/> Soon after the software was installed on [[Compaq]] [[laptops]] that accompanied U.S. troops during the [[First Gulf War]], where it was used to requisition "everything from [[Coca-Cola]] to [[Outhouse|privies]]".<ref name="Softwarriors p34"/> Other significant volume sales went to [[3M]] and [[Rockwell International]].<ref name="Softwarriors p34"/> What helped set apart Delrina's electronic forms from its competitors in product reviews included its easy-to-use interface, its extensive development tools, and its comparatively low price.<ref name="FormTest">{{Cite journal | title = Putting electronic forms to the test | journal = InfoWorld | pages = 93–105 | date = May 2, 1994 }}</ref> It also scored highly when it came to workflow and routing functions as well as security features.<ref name="Melnitsky">{{Cite journal | last = Melnitsky | first = Stuart | title = Form is function | journal = Network World | page = 48 | date = December 2, 1996 }}</ref> In early 1991 [[InfoWorld]] selected PerForm Pro as its "Product of the Year" in the electronic forms category, and [[PC World Magazine]] gave the product it's "Best Buy" designation.<ref name="ProductOfTheYear1990">{{cite press release | title = Delrina's PerFORM Chosen Product of the Year | publisher = Delrina Technology Inc. | date = February 18, 1991 }}</ref> PerForm proved to be successful in its niche, effectively capturing the retail market by 1993.<ref name="Kevin Strehlo p.88">{{Cite journal | last = Strehlo | first = Kevin | title = FormFlow has the smarts to truly automate form routing | journal = Network World | page = 88 | date = July 12, 1993 }}</ref>
The electronic forms division of Delrina was sold to [[JetForm]] in 1996. JetForm in turn was bought by [[Adobe Systems|Adobe]], and the electronic forms products were officially discontinued in 2004.

{{about|the lobbyist|the footballer|Roman Janoušek (footballer)}} {{Infobox person | image = <!-- Only freely-licensed images may be used to depict living people. See [[WP:NONFREE]]. --> | image_size = 150px | | name = Roman Janoušek | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1968|7|3}} | birth_place = [[Czechoslovakia]] | residence = | nationality = Czech | known_for = | education = | occupation = businessman, lobbyist | title = [[Doctor of law|JUDr.]] | networth = | spouse = Simona Janoušková | partner = | children = }} '''Roman Janoušek''' (born 3 July 1968) is an influential billionaire businessman and [[lobbyist]] from the [[Czech Republic]].<ref name="BBC">{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-17521319 | title=Fall of Czech lobbyist Janousek dubbed 'Voldemort' | publisher=BBC | accessdate=March 28, 2012}}</ref> In November 2014 he started serving a 4.5-year sentence he received for his hit-and-run automobile accident in March 2012.
==Business activities== In June 1993 Janoušek co-founded Medea Real. He later made a lot of money in magazine publishing and real estate.
==Allegations of corruption== Janoušek has been under investigation regarding allegations of tender-rigging and [[bribery]]. It is also alleged that his friendship with [[Pavel Bém]], mayor of [[Prague]] between 2002 and 2010, helped him in developing his business activities.<ref name="BBC"/> He was one of the targets of the [[2013 Czech political corruption scandal]] which led to the downfall of [[List of Prime Ministers of the Czech Republic|Prime Minister]] [[Petr Nečas]] and his [[Petr Nečas's Cabinet|coalition government]].
==Hit-and-run== On April 30, 2014, Janoušek was handed a 3-year prison sentence for a [[Hit and run (vehicular)|hit-and-run]] accident that took place in Prague in March 2012. It is claimed that he had been driving drunk when he collided with another car. He ran over the 51-year-old woman driver causing grievous bodily harm when she attempted to stop him from leaving the scene. Janoušek faced ten years in prison.<ref name="Czech Radio">{{cite web | url=http://radio.cz/en/section/curraffrs/prague-court-sentences-infamous-political-fixer-to-three-years-in-prison | title=Prague court sentences infamous political fixer to three years in prison | publisher=Radio Praha | accessdate=April 30, 2014}}</ref> Both the prosecution and Janoušek appealed the verdict.<ref name="ihned140430">http://zpravy.ihned.cz/cesko/c1-62110180-janousek-je-vinen-rekl-soud-za-nehodu-ma-jit-na-tri-roky-za-mrize-a-pet-let-nesmi-ridit</ref> The court eventually decided to increase Janoušek's prison sentence to 4.5 years and raised the term of his driving ban from 5 years to 7, stating that the injury sustained by the other driver was not the result of an accident but of a deliberate criminal act on the part of Janoušek.<ref>http://zpravy.idnes.cz/roman-janousek-u-vrchniho-soudu-dap-/krimi.aspx?c=A140915_152949_krimi_cen</ref> On November 18, 2014, Janoušek began serving his sentence in the Brno city jail.<ref>http://zpravy.idnes.cz/janousek-musi-nastoupit-do-vezeni-d54-/krimi.aspx?c=A141118_101943_krimi_bse</ref> Both the prosecution and Janoušek appealed to the [[Supreme Court of the Czech Republic]] but the verdict was upheld on July 28, 2015.<ref>http://zpravy.aktualne.cz/domaci/trest-pro-janouska-plati-nejvyssi-soud-dovolani-zamitl/r~c5c2ba30353411e593f4002590604f2e/</ref>

{{for|the Union Army officer|Samuel K. Vaughan}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} '''Samuel Vaughan''' (1720–1802) was an English merchant, plantation owner, and political radical. [[File:Samuel Vaughan Pine.jpg|thumb|Samuel Vaughan, 1760 portrait by [[Robert Edge Pine]]]]
==Early life== Born in Ireland, Vaughan's parents were Benjamin Vaughan and Ann Wolf; he was the youngest of a family of 12.<ref>[http://tclf.org/pioneer/samuel-vaughan/biography-samuel-vaughan Cultural Landscape Foundation, ''Biography of Samuel Vaughan''.]</ref> He was a merchant and plantation owner, living largely in [[Jamaica]], from 1736 to 1752, when he set up business as a [[merchant bank]]er at Dunster's Court, [[Mincing Lane]], in the [[City of London]].<ref name="Bos">{{cite book|author=James Boswell|title=The general correspondence of James Boswell, 1766–1769: 1768–1769. Vol. 2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Aqbs1VnYC7IC&pg=PA239|accessdate=18 May 2013|year=1997|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|isbn=978-0-7486-0810-2|page=239 note 1}}</ref><ref name="Laurens1980">{{cite book|author=Henry Laurens|title=The Papers of Henry Laurens, Volume 8: October 10, 1771 – April 19, 1773|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KgJ-tRd11MUC&pg=PA327|accessdate=18 May 2013|date=1 April 1980|publisher=Univ of South Carolina Press|isbn=978-0-87249-385-8|page=327 note 6}}</ref>
==Political activist== In politics Vaughan supported [[John Wilkes]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Peter D. G. Thomas|title=John Wilkes: A Friend to Liberty|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gU_43lc9JIUC&pg=PA112|accessdate=17 May 2013|date=28 March 1996|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0-19-820544-9|page=112}}</ref> He sent his five sons to [[Warrington Academy]],<ref>Ben, 1766–73; William, 1766–69; John, 1772–74; Charles, 1775–77; Samuel, 1777–79. (Dissenting Academies Online: http://dissacad.english.qmul.ac.uk).</ref> Benjamin and William being taught by [[Joseph Priestley]], with whom a strong family connection was forged.<ref>Graham, p. 103.</ref> In early 1769 Vaughan was using his contact with [[John Seddon of Warrington]] to circulate [[John Wilkes|Wilkite]] literature in Lancashire.<ref>{{cite book|author=William McCarthy|title=Anna Letitia Barbauld: Voice of the Enlightenment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kTZL66z4CF0C&pg=PA99|accessdate=18 May 2013|date=23 December 2008|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-0-8018-9016-1|page=99}}</ref> He also hoped to recruit supporters in [[Manchester]] and [[Liverpool]] through Seddon.<ref>Graham, p. 98 note 229.</ref> With [[Joseph Mawbey]] and others, Vaughan was a founder of the [[Bill of Rights Society]] (Society of Gentlemen Supporters of the Bill of Rights).<ref>{{cite book|author=[[George Rudé]]|title=Hanoverian London: 1714 – 1808|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FjzoBBXDcZAC&pg=PA173|accessdate=18 May 2013|year=1971|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-01778-8|page=173}}</ref> It was a trust giving financial support to Wilkes, and the treasurers were Vaughan, [[Richard Oliver (MP)|Richard Oliver]] and John Trevanion (1740–1810). The Society set about dealing with Wilkes's tangled money affairs.<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=73620|title=Society of Gentlemen Supporters of the Bill of Rights|first=Nicola|last=Jones}}</ref>
Vaughan belonged to what [[Benjamin Franklin]] fondly called the Club of Honest Whigs, which met at St Paul's Coffee-house in St Paul's-churchyard.<ref>{{cite book|author=Robert E Schofield|title="The" Enlightened Joseph Priestley: A Study of His Life and Work from 1773 to 1804|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qL9K2e4KIvsC&pg=PA18|accessdate=17 May 2013|year=2004|publisher=Penn State Press|isbn=978-0-271-04624-2|page=18}}</ref> His support for the cause of [[Corsica]] in 1768 brought him the acquaintance of [[James Boswell]] through the Club.<ref>Verner W. Crane, ''The Club of Honest Whigs: Friends of Science and Liberty'', The William and Mary Quarterly Third Series, Vol. 23, No. 2 (Apr. 1966), pp. 210–233, at p. 228. Published by: Omohundro Institute of Early American History and Culture. Stable URL: https://www.jstor.org/stable/1922508</ref> Vaughan was a trustee of funds for Corsica, with [[William Beckford (politician)|William Beckford]] and [[Barlow Trecothick]].<ref>{{cite book|author=William McCarthy|title=Anna Letitia Barbauld: Voice of the Enlightenment|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kTZL66z4CF0C&pg=PA578|accessdate=18 May 2013|date=23 December 2008|publisher=JHU Press|isbn=978-0-8018-9016-1|page=578 note 10}}</ref>
In December 1774 [[Benjamin Franklin]] and [[Josiah Quincy II]] stayed with Vaughan at [[Wanstead]] in Essex.<ref name="Quincy2009">{{cite book|author=Josiah Quincy|title=Memoir of the Life of Josiah Quincy, Jun. of Massachusetts|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vt6fAsehB1wC&pg=PA252|accessdate=18 May 2013|date=1 June 2009|publisher=Applewood Books|isbn=978-1-4290-1688-9|pages=252–3}}</ref> In the period 1781–2 the parliamentary reformer [[Christopher Wyvill]] met radical leaders at Vaughan's house.<ref>{{cite book|author=E. C. Black|title=The Association: British Extra-parliamentary Political Organization, 1769–1793|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=A1Sw-IZGLJ4C&pg=PA84|accessdate=18 May 2013|year=1963|publisher=Harvard University Press|isbn=978-0-674-05000-6|page=84}}</ref> There resulted a political pact for the following session of parliament, of mutual support between Wyvill and a radical group around Vaughan (including [[John Jebb (reformer)|John Jebb]], [[John Horne Tooke]], and [[James Townsend (Lord Mayor of London)|James Townsend]]).<ref>{{cite book |author=John M. Norris |title=Shelburne and Reform |year=1963 |publisher=Macmillan |page=162}}</ref> Vaughan joined the [[Society for Constitutional Information]] in the 1780s.<ref>Graham, p. 43 note 39.</ref> Through William Beckford, he met the [[William Petty, 2nd Earl of Shelburne|Earl of Shelburne]]. When Shelburne became Prime Minister, the Vaughan family influence reached foreign policy, trying to split the United States from their French allies in some ultimately unsuccessful moves of 1782.<ref>{{cite book |author=John M. Norris |title=Shelburne and Reform |year=1963 |publisher=Macmillan |pages= 58 and 165}}</ref>
The Vaughan family was part of the congregation of the dissenting minister [[Richard Price]].<ref>[http://www.amphilsoc.org/mole/view?docId=ead/Mss.B.V462-ead.xml amphilsoc.org, ''John Vaughan papers, 1768 – Circa 1936''.]</ref> Samuel Vaughan was a friend of the elder [[William Hazlitt (Unitarian minister)|William Hazlitt]], the Unitarian minister.<ref>{{cite ODNB|id=95498|title=Hazlitt, William|first=Duncan|last=Wu}}</ref> Vaughan's religious views have been described as "free-thinking Unitarian".<ref name="Ryden">{{cite book |author=David Beck Ryden |title=West Indian Slavery and British Abolition |year=2009 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=9780521486590 |page=64}}</ref>
==Jamaica and bribery scandal== Vaughan purchased in 1765 the post of Clerk to the [[Supreme Court of Jamaica]]. In 1769 Vaughan then offered the [[Augustus FitzRoy, 3rd Duke of Grafton|Duke of Grafton]], a government minister, a sum of £5000 to secure a reversion, to hold this official place in the family for three of his sons.<ref name="Bos"/> Grafton brought a [[King's Bench]] case against Vaughan, which resulted in embarrassment to both parties. The prominence of the issue led the campaigning writer [[Junius]] to expose a previous sale of office by Grafton. This was the post of Collector of Customs in [[Exeter]], to a Mr. Hine, for which Grafton took £3,500; and the implication was that the money went to a card-sharp.<ref>{{cite book |author=Bernard Falk |title= The Royal Fitz Roys|year=1950 |publisher=Hutchinson |page=108}}</ref>
Vaughan put his side of the case in ''An Appeal to the Public on Behalf of Samuel Vaughan, Esq. in a fall and impartial Narrative of his Negotiation with the Duke of Grafton'';<ref name="Bos"/> and Grafton dropped the prosecution.<ref>{{cite book|author=Richard Lee Bradshaw|title=Thomas Bradshaw (1733–1774): A Georgian Politician in the Time of the American Revolution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GHorngsRYdAC&pg=PA90|accessdate=18 May 2013|date=12 August 2011|publisher=Xlibris Corporation|isbn=978-1-4653-4479-3|page=90}}</ref> Even so, Vaughan's actions appeared to be a political gaffe to some of the political radicals, Vaughan's allies. [[Anna Barbauld]], a family friend, wrote a poem complimenting his wife Sarah as a gesture of support.<ref>{{cite book|author=Harriet Guest|title=Small Change: Women, Learning, Patriotism, 1750–1810|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nYXIaWSvBTAC&pg=PA233|accessdate=20 May 2013|date=1 December 2000|publisher=University of Chicago Press|isbn=978-0-226-31052-7|page=233 note 27}}</ref>
Some of Vaughan's sons became involved in the plantation business, and its London end Vaughan & Co. Benjamin visited Jamaica in the early 1770s, and in parliament in the 1790s defended [[slavery]] on the island. William worked in the company, and became prominent in the London Society of West India Merchants.<ref name="Ryden"/> Vaughan himself visited Jamaica again in 1775.<ref>{{cite book|title=Proceedings, American Philosophical Society (vol. 116, No. 3, 1972)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YkkLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA270|accessdate=19 May 2013|publisher=American Philosophical Society|isbn=978-1-4223-7123-7|page=270 note 9}}</ref> The Vaughan estates were Flamstead and Vaughansfield in [[Saint James Parish, Jamaica]], slave-run sugar plantations.<ref>{{cite book|author=Lady Maria Nugent|title=Lady Nugent's Journal of Her Residence in Jamaïca from 1801 to 1805|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yavJoHc3138C&pg=PA242|accessdate=20 May 2013|year=2002|publisher=University Press of the West Indies|isbn=978-976-640-128-3|page=242}}</ref> Vaughansfield was involved in the [[Second Maroon War]] in the neighbouring [[Trelawny Parish]].<ref name="Craton2009">{{cite book|author=Michael Craton|title=Testing the Chains: Resistance to Slavery in the British West Indies|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qP2jDoiqy3wC&pg=PA214|accessdate=20 May 2013|year=2009|publisher=Cornell University Press|isbn=978-0-8014-7528-3|page=214}}</ref> Samuel Vaughan junior became proprietor of these estates.<ref name="Ryden"/>
==In the United States== After the end of the [[American War of Independence]] Vaughan made several long stays in the United States. There were three separate visits.<ref>{{cite book|author=John Hannibal Sheppard|title=Reminiscences of the Vaughan Family: And More Particularly of Benjamin Vaughan, LL.D.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=JvUUAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA31|accessdate=20 May 2013|year=1865|publisher=D. Clapp & son, printers|page=31}}</ref> Vaughan was accompanied by his family, but sent them home in 1786.<ref name="Graham, p. 60">Graham, p. 60.</ref> He wrote to Richard Price in 1785 of the American principles of government as being "the permanent security of the rights of mankind".<ref>Graham, p. 51.</ref>
===Philadelphia and Virginia=== Vaughan was on good terms with [[George Washington]];<ref>{{cite book|author1=William Meade Stith Rasmussen|author2=Robert S. Tilton|title=George Washington—the Man Behind the Myths|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NsNMnx5YTRoC&pg=PA205|accessdate=17 May 2013|year=1999|publisher=University of Virginia Press|isbn=978-0-8139-1900-3|page=205}}</ref> Washington wrote to him on 30 November 1785 about gifts of a pamphlet of [[Honoré Gabriel Riqueti, comte de Mirabeau|Mirabeau]] on the [[Society of the Cincinnati]], and Jamaican [[rum]].<ref>John Clement Fitzpatrick, David Maydole Matteson (editors), ''The Writings of George Washington from the Original Manuscript Sources, 1745–1799; prepared under the direction of the United States George Washington Bicentennial Commission and published by authority of Congress'' vol. 28 (1931), pp. 326–8; [https://archive.org/stream/writingsofgeorge28wash#page/326/mode/2up archive.org.]</ref> They had met in [[Philadelphia]] in December 1783. There Vaughan planned the planting of the [[Independence Hall|State House]] garden, as well as laying out the gardens of [[Gray's Ferry Tavern]] in the English style.<ref name="Wulf84">{{cite book|author=Andrea Wulf|authorlink = Andrea Wulf|title=The Founding Gardeners: How the Revolutionary Generation Created an American Eden|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T9KWQslMe9QC&pg=PA84|accessdate=20 May 2013|date=2 April 2012|publisher=Windmill Books|isbn=978-0-09-952562-2|page=84 and note}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Hans Huth|title=Nature and the American: three centuries of changing attitudes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1M5GcVUY8MgC&pg=RA1-PA59|accessdate=20 May 2013|year=1957|publisher=U of Nebraska Press|isbn=978-0-8032-7247-7|page=59}}</ref> In Philadelphia also, with [[Francis Hopkinson]], he helped revive the [[American Philosophical Society]]; and provided a sketch-plan for [[Philosophical Hall]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Edward Clark Carter|title="One Grand Pursuit": A Brief History of the American Philosophical Society's First 250 Years, 1743–1993. 1743- 1993|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=iV0GqW1cIJYC&pg=PA16|accessdate=19 May 2013|year=1993|publisher=American Philosophical Society|isbn=978-0-87169-938-1|page=16}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Proceedings, American Philosophical Society (vol. 116, No. 3, 1972)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YkkLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA270|accessdate=19 May 2013|publisher=American Philosophical Society|isbn=978-1-4223-7123-7|page=270}}</ref>
As Vaughan explained to [[Humphry Marshall]], he planned to plant the State House Yard with a representative collection of American trees and shrubs.<ref>[http://specialcollections.nal.usda.gov/vaughan-marshall-may-28-1785-usda-history-collection specialcollections.nal.usda.gov, ''Vaughan to Marshall, May 28, 1785, USDA History Collection''.]</ref> The ambition was a political statement, on the unity of the newly United States, and was shared by Washington and [[Thomas Jefferson]] as gardeners.<ref>{{cite book|author=Andrea Wulf|authorlink = Andrea Wulf|title=The Founding Gardeners: How the Revolutionary Generation Created an American Eden|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T9KWQslMe9QC&pg=PA84|accessdate=20 May 2013|date=2 April 2012|publisher=Windmill Books|isbn=978-0-09-952562-2|pages=118–9}}</ref> In Philadelphia for the [[Constitutional Convention (United States)|Constitutional Convention]] during the summer of 1787, Vaughan paid a visit in July to [[William Bartram]]'s nursery, from which he ordered 55 species of plants.<ref name="Wulf84"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Andrea Wulf|authorlink = Andrea Wulf|title=The Founding Gardeners: How the Revolutionary Generation Created an American Eden|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T9KWQslMe9QC&pg=PA84|accessdate=20 May 2013|date=2 April 2012|publisher=Windmill Books|isbn=978-0-09-952562-2|pages=79}}</ref> The State House project's greater scope was abandoned, but Vaughan saw to the publication of Marshall's ''Arbustum Americanum'', in 1785.<ref>Joseph Ewan, ''Seeds and Ships and Healing Herbs, Encouragers and Kings'', Bartonia No. 45 (1978), pp. 24–29, at pp. 28–29. Published by: Philadelphia Botanical Club. Stable URL: https://www.jstor.org/stable/41609821</ref> He was elected a Fellow of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] in 1786.<ref name=AAAS>{{cite web|title=Book of Members, 1780–2010: Chapter V|url=http://www.amacad.org/publications/BookofMembers/ChapterV.pdf|publisher=American Academy of Arts and Sciences|accessdate=28 July 2014}}</ref>
In 1787 also, Vaughan visited [[Mount Vernon]], and drew a plan of the garden.<ref>{{cite book|author=Andrea Wulf|authorlink = Andrea Wulf|title=The Founding Gardeners: How the Revolutionary Generation Created an American Eden|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=T9KWQslMe9QC&pg=PA24|accessdate=20 May 2013|date=2 April 2012|publisher=Windmill Books|isbn=978-0-09-952562-2|page=24}}</ref> He gave Washington a marble mantelpiece for the house.<ref name="Graham, p. 60"/> [[File:American Philosophical Society West side.jpg|thumb|left|Philosophical Hall, Philadelphia today]]
===Maine=== Vaughan also spent time in [[Hallowell, Maine]], meeting up with William Hazlitt there in the winter of 1784–5.<ref>{{cite book|author=George Willis Cooke|title=Unitarianism in America: A History of Its Origin and Development|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fd_KV5GYPZUC&pg=PA51|accessdate=20 May 2013|date=31 December 2007|publisher=Echo Library|isbn=978-1-4068-4830-4|page=51}}</ref> Sarah Vaughan had inherited property on the [[Kennebec River]], from her father, who was a "Kennebeck Proprietor", and also a congregationalist supporter of the [[Brattle Square Church]].<ref>Properly, one of The Proprietors of the Kennebec Purchase from the late Colony of New-Plymouth.</ref><ref>{{cite book |author=Gordon E. Kershaw |title=The Kennebeck Proprietors: 1749–1775 |year=1975|publisher=New Hampshire Publishing Co. |isbn=0912274492 |pages=28–30 and 240}}</ref><ref name="Lib">{{cite book|author=Alan Taylor|title=Liberty Men and Great Proprietors: The Revolutionary Settlement on the Maine Frontier, 1760 – 1820|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mGnugGea5OEC&pg=PA35|accessdate=20 May 2013|year=1990|publisher=UNC Press Books|isbn=978-0-8078-4282-9|pages=34–7}}</ref> Two of the Vaughan sons (Benjamin and Charles) settled there, and another (John, a business partner of [[Robert Morris (financier)|Robert Morris]]) at Philadelphia.<ref name="Berard">''Arlington and Mount Vernon 1856. As Described in a Letter of Augusta Blanche Berard'', The Virginia Magazine of History and Biography Vol. 57, No. 2 (Apr. 1949), pp. 140–175, at p. 169. Published by: Virginia Historical Society. Stable URL: https://www.jstor.org/stable/4245617</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Charles Rappleye|title=Robert Morris: Financier of the American Revolution|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dELO9Pc3P50C&pg=P368|accessdate=20 May 2013|date=2 November 2010|publisher=Simon & Schuster|isbn=978-1-4165-7286-2|page=368}}</ref> Samuel Vaughan in fact intended a religious project in the area, which was put in the hands of Charles, who became a "Kennebeck Proprietor"; but the original aim became muted as Charles's lack of business acumen showed through.<ref name="Lib"/>
==Later life== In 1790 Vaughan attended the funeral of his friend Benjamin Franklin. Shortly afterwards he returned to London.<ref name="Graham, p. 60"/> In 1792 he went to Paris to attend debates of the [[National Assembly (French Revolution)|National Assembly]].<ref>Graham, p. 344 note 10.</ref> In 1795 he bought the "Vaughan portrait", one of many portraits of Washington by [[Gilbert Stuart]].<ref>[http://www.nga.gov/content/ngaweb/Collection/art-object-page.1121.html nga.gov, ''George Washington (Vaughan portrait)''.]</ref> [[File:George Washington (Vaughan portrait) A33850.jpg|thumb|George Washington, the Vaughan Portrait (1795)]]
Vaughan died in [[Hackney parish|Hackney]], in 1802.<ref>{{cite book|author=[[John Towill Rutt]]|title=Life and correspondence of Joseph Priestley, LL.D., F.R.S., &c|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NtkEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA59|accessdate=2 June 2013|year=1831|publisher=R. Hunter|page=59 note}}</ref>
==Family== Vaughan married Sarah Hallowell (1727–1809), daughter of Benjamin Hallowell. They had 11 children in all.<ref name="Laurens1980"/> Ten lived to be adults. Of those, their sons were:
*[[Benjamin Vaughan|Benjamin]] *[[William Vaughan (merchant)|William]] *[[John Vaughan (wine merchant)]] (1756–1841) *Charles (1759–1839), married Frances Western Apthorp.<ref name="Berard"/><ref>{{cite book|author=Alan Taylor|title=Liberty Men and Great Proprietors: The Revolutionary Settlement on the Maine Frontier, 1760 – 1820|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mGnugGea5OEC&pg=PA35|accessdate=17 May 2013|year=1990|publisher=UNC Press Books|isbn=978-0-8078-4282-9|page=35}}</ref> *[[Samuel Vaughan junior|Samuel junior]] (1762–1827) [[File:Sarah Hallowell Vaughan.jpg|thumb|left|Sarah Hallowell Vaughan]] Their daughters were
* Anne, or Ann, who married John Darby and was mother to [[John Nelson Darby]]<ref>{{cite book|title=Proceedings, American Philosophical Society (vol. 116, No. 3, 1972)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YkkLAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA270|accessdate=19 May 2013|publisher=American Philosophical Society|isbn=978-1-4223-7123-7|page=270 note 8}}</ref><ref>{{cite ODNB|id=7141|title=Darby, John Nelson|first=Timothy C. F.|last=Stunt}}</ref> * Rebecca married John Merrick, and was mother of [[Samuel Vaughan Merrick]].<ref>{{cite book|author=Daniel Raynes Goodwin|title=Memoir of John Merrick, Esq.|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mi9AAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA7|accessdate=18 May 2013|year=1862|publisher=Henry B. Ashmead, book and job printer|page=7}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Pennsylvania Biographical Dictionary|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=0HqhGvQF4CQC&pg=RA1-PA150|accessdate=18 May 2013|publisher=North American Book Dist LLC|isbn=978-0-403-09950-4|pages=150}}</ref> *Barbara Eddy, Sarah, Hannah.<ref>[http://www.masshist.org/findingaids/doc.cfm?fa=fa0040 masshist.org, ''Vaughan Family Papers 1768–1950, Guide to the Collection''.]</ref>
==References== *Jenny Graham (2000), ''The Nation, the Law, and the King: Reform Politics in England, 1789–1799'', 2 volumes
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==External links== *''The Vaughan Family'': {{cite book|author=NEHGS|title=The New England Historical and Genealogical Register 1865|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ughuKMdwTQ4C&pg=PA343|accessdate=18 May 2013|date=June 1994|publisher=Heritage Books|isbn=978-1-55613-976-5|page=343}}
{{authority control}}

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Chinese name|[[She (surname)|Seah]] ({{zh|c=佘|p=Shé}})}}
{{Infobox person | name = Seah Eu Chin | birth_date = {{Birth date|1805|08|30}} | birth_place = [[Guangdong]], [[China]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|1883|09|23|1805|08|30}} | death_place = [[Singapore]] | nationality = Naturalized British subject | other_names = Siah U-Chin | occupation = Merchant, financier | known_for = Founder of [[Ngee Ann Kongsi]] }}
'''Seah Eu Chin''' ({{zh|c=佘有進|p=Shé Yǒujìn}}; [[Pseudonym|a.k.a.]] '''Siah U-chin''', '''Seah Uchin''' or '''Seah You Chin'''; 1805{{dash}}1883) was an immigrant from South China to Singapore, later becoming a successful merchant and leader in the [[Overseas Chinese]] community.
He is a prominent descendant of '''[[She (surname)|Seah Clan]]''' in Southeast Asia.
== Early life ==
Seah Eu Chin was born in 1805 as the son of Seah Keng Liat ({{zh|c=佘慶烈|p=Shé Qìngliè}}), a minor provincial official of ''Guek-po'' (i.e. {{zh|"[[:zh:月浦街道|月浦]]"}} in [[Teochew dialect]]) ''Village'' at the [[Chenghai District|Chenghai County]] of the former ''[[Chaozhou]] [[Fu (country subdivision)|Fu]]''. He was educated in Chinese classics in his youth, but decided to seek his fortune abroad. He came to Singapore in 1823, first working as a clerk, then becoming a plantation owner and finally becoming a trader and a merchant.<ref name="SongOngSiang">{{cite book | last=Song | first=Ong Siang | author-link=Song Ong Siang | title=One Hundred Years' History of the Chinese in Singapore | publisher=John Murray | date=1923 | location=London | language=English | url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/printheritage/download.aspx?id=f8082431-1c7b-460e-b59c-bbc5793035a3}}</ref>{{rp|19}}
== Plantation and mercantile activity ==
Seah Eu Chin was a successful plantation owner. He was the first to plant [[Gambier (extract)|gambier]] (or white cutch) on a large scale in Singapore. By 1839, his gambier plantation had stretched for eight to ten miles, from the upper end of River Valley Road to Bukit Timah Road and Thomson Road. Mr Seah's holdings earned him the title: 'King of Gambier'. He made his fortune in gambier and [[Black pepper|pepper]] plantations. However, by the 1850s–60s, the planting of gambier and pepper was becoming less profitable in Singapore for several reasons, including the increasing scarcity of uncleared land for planting (gambier quickly exhausted the soil and so plantations had to keep shifting), the shortage of firewood from the clearing of forests, and the lack of land on Singapore Island itself.
Therefore, in his later years, he became involved in trading as a merchant and agent under the name of Eu Chin Co. which was based in North Bridge Road. His sons, especially the eldest, Seah Cheo Seah, and second son [[Seah Liang Seah]], helped manage the business, as did his brother-in-law, Tan Seng Poh.
==Family life==
In 1837, he married a daughter of [[Tan Ah Hun]], the [[Kapitan Cina|Kapitan (Captain) China]] (i.e. leader of the Chinese community) of [[Perak]].<ref>{{cite book | last =Wong | first =Choon-san | title =A gallery of Chinese kapitans | publisher =Dewan Bahasa dan Kebudayaan Kebangsaan | date =1963 | location =Singapore | language =English}}</ref> She died soon after from the effects of [[smallpox]], and about a year later, he married her sister with whom he had several children. His brother-in-law, [[Tan Seng Poh]], came with his sister to Singapore to be educated there. Seng Poh was an [[opium]] and spirit farmer (i.e. he ran a government-tendered monopoly processing raw [[opium]] imported from [[British India]]. The Opium and Spirit [[Farm (revenue leasing)|Farm]], or Excise, was the main source of income for the Straits Settlements<ref>{{cite book |last=Trocki |first=Carl A. |author-link=Carl A. Trocki |date=1990 |title=Opium and empire : Chinese society in Colonial Singapore, 1800-1910 |location=Ithaca, New York |publisher=Cornell University Press |isbn=0801423902}}</ref>) and helped manage Eu Chin's mercantile firm after the latter's retirement in 1864. Most prominent among his children were [[Seah Liang Seah]] and [[Seah Peck Seah]], both of whom also became Justices of the Peace and prominent members of the Chinese community; the former was also an unofficial member of the [[Legislative Council of the Straits Settlements]]. His eldest son, Seah Cheo Seah, was also a J.P. but he died only two years after his father, in 1885. He had another son, Seah Song Seah, who died in China, and three daughters, about whom very little is known.<ref name="SongOngSiang" />{{rp|21}}
== Community leadership ==
In 1830, he and representatives of twelve Teochew clans set up the Ngee Ann Kun which later became the [[Ngee Ann Kongsi]] in 1845. He was the chairman of the Kongsi until his death whereupon power passed to his sons Seah Cheo Seah and Seah Liang Seah, followed by his grandson Seah Eng Tong, resulting in a Seah monopoly on power in the Kongsi until 1928. Resentment against them caused the formation of another Teochew clan association, the [[Teochew Poit Ip Huay Kuan]].<ref>{{cite |last=Yen |first=Ching-hwang |title=A social history of the Chinese in Singapore and Malaya 1800-1911 |location=Singapore |publisher=Oxford University Press |date=1986 |isbn= 0195826663 |pages=190}}</ref>
Seah Eu Chin helped run [[Tan Tock Seng Hospital]] when it was first set up, being a member, and in some years treasurer, of its management committee.
Just as the European merchant community used Chinese middlemen in conducting their business, the [[Straits Settlements]] government relied on prominent Chinese businessmen to act as go-betweens with the Chinese community. Seah Eu Chin was the go-between with the Teochew community, which originated from the [[Chaozhou]] province of Southern China. He rendered service in helping to quell several disturbances in the community, most notably the 1854 Hokkien-Teochew Riots which broke out on 5 May 1854. The incident ostensibly began because of a dispute over the price of rice, between a [[Hokkien]] and a Teochew, but that dispute probably was only a trigger for the release of long-held resentment and animosity between the Hokkien (from [[Fujian]] province in China) and Teochew (from Chaozhou province) communities.<ref>{{cite encyclopedia | last=Yong |first=Chun Yuan | title =Hokkien-Teochew Riots (1854) | encyclopedia =Singapore Infopedia | publisher =National Library Board, Singapore | date =2016 | url=http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/infopedia/articles/SIP_104_2005-01-25.html | access-date =2017-07-19 }}</ref> In all over 400 people were killed over 10 days of violence. The British authorities on Singapore island met with Chinese leaders, including Seah Eu Chin representing Teochews and [[Tan Kim Ching]] representing the Hokkiens, and with their assistance helped to bring the situation to a close.
He was an early member of the [[Singapore Chamber of Commerce]], established in 1837, and was made a [[Justice of the Peace]] in 1867. He had also been a member of the [[Grand Jury]] since 1851, and also had cases involving Chinese referred to him by the court. In 1872, he was made an honorary police magistrate, along with four other Chinese including his brother-in-law Tan Seng Poh.
== Last years ==
Seah Eu Chin finally retired from business in 1864, to concentrate on scholarly pursuits, though he still had an interest in community affairs. For instance, his name is with that of several other Chinese on a petition submitted to the government requesting the suppression of illegal "Wah-Weh" gambling among the Chinese community. In the last decade of his life he lived in a mansion built by his son Seah Cheo Seah that was among the [[Four Mansions]] ({{lang-zh|c=四大厝|p=Sì dà cuò}}) of the 19th-century Chinese in Singapore.<ref>{{Cite book|title=马来亚丛谈|last=Hsu|first=Yun-tsiao|publisher=Youth Book Co.|year=2005|isbn=9810540213|location=Singapore|pages=115-124|orig-year=1961}}</ref>
He died on 23 September 1883, and his widow in 1905.<ref name="SongOngSiang" />{{rp|22}} He was buried in the family estate near the SLF Building along [[Thomson Road, Singapore|Thomson Road]]. His tomb was re-discovered in late 2012.<ref>{{cite news | last =Boon | first =Rachel | title =Teochew pioneer's grave found in Toa Payoh | newspaper =Straits Times | location =Singapore | language =English | date =2012-11-28 | url =http://www.asiaone.com/print/News/Latest%2BNews/Singapore/Story/A1Story20121126-385931.html | access-date =2017-07-19 }}</ref>
Several streets in Singapore are named for Seah Eu Chin and his sons, namely Eu Chin Street, Liang Seah Street, and Peck Seah Street. Seah Street, in [[Bras Basah]], is named for the Seah family.
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Further reading == {{cite book | last =Buckley | first =Charles Burton | author-link = | title =An anecdotal history of old times in Singapore | publisher =Fraser and Neave | location =Singapore | date =1902 | language =English | url =http://eresources.nlb.gov.sg/printheritage/detail/303beefb-31d7-4dad-83fb-593054096717.aspx?s=anecdotal%20history%20buckley }}
{{cite journal | last =Siah | first =U-Chin | author-link =Seah Eu Chin | title =General sketch of the numbers, tribes, and avocations of the Chinese in Singapore | journal =Journal of the Indian Archipelago and Eastern Asia | volume =2 | pages =283-289 | publisher =J.R. Logan | location =Singapore | date =1848 | language =English }}

{{notability|Places|date=June 2018}} {{unreferenced|date=June 2018}} '''Segensworth''' is a [[business park]] near [[Whiteley]] / [[Fareham]] in [[Hampshire]] in [[England]]. . At the 2011 Census the business park was included in the Park Gate Ward of Fareham Council.
==Location==
Segensworth is located in southern Hampshire between the cities of [[Portsmouth]] and [[Southampton]] and close to the market town of Fareham. It is off junction 9 of the [[M27 motorway (England)|M27]] while rail services are provided nearby at [[Swanwick railway station]].
It also has excellent cycle lanes from [[Fareham]] and towards [[Southampton]] and the nearby Train station
== History ==
Segensworth original farmland which was developed in a joint venture between Winchester and Fareham Council, into an industrial estate during the 1980s due to its adjacency to the M27 which provides excellent access to nearby Ports and arterial roads to [[London]] such as the M3 and A3
== Business improvement district ==
Segensworth has been a [[Business improvement district]] since 2012, information on the impact provided can be found on the [http://www.sbfl.co.uk/ Segensworth Business forum website]
==External links==
{{coord|50.86949|N|1.25051|W|type:landmark_region:GB|display=title}}

{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=September 2014}} {{Unreferenced|date=April 2009}} }}
'''Semantic Intelligence''' is the ability to gather the necessary information to allow to identify, detect and solve [[semantic gap]]s on all level of the organization.
Similar to [[Operational Intelligence]] or [[Operational Intelligence|Business Process Intelligence]], which aims to identify, detect and then optimize business processes, semantic intelligence targets information instead of processes. It aims to enable better understanding and insight in data by all stakeholders. This will support better information sharing, reuse and governance and support better business decision-making.
== Semantic Gap ==
Several types of semantic gaps can be identified: # The semantic gap between different data sources - structured or unstructured # The semantic gap between the operational data and the human interpretation of this data # The semantic gap between people communicating about a certain information concept.
One application of semantic intelligence is the management of [[unstructured information]], leveraging [[semantic technology]]. These applications tackle R&D, sales, marketing and security for activities that include [[Knowledge Management]], [[Customer Care]] and [[Corporate Intelligence]].
Several applications aim to detect and solve different types of semantic gaps. They range from [[search engine]]s to automatic categorizers, from [[ETL system]]s to [[natural language]] interfaces, special functionality include [[dashboard]]s and [[text mining]].
One approach that aims to provide a holistic solution to achieve semantic intelligence is [[Business semantics management]]. Instead of focusing on very specific type of semantic gap (i.e. unstructured data), it aims to provide a whole solution to align business and it to share the understanding and semantics of information concepts.
== History ==
In 2002, the software company [[Expert System S.p.A.]] started to popularize Semantic Intelligence as a term to describe a new generation of information access technology applications based on semantic analysis. In opposition to standard systems to process unstructured information (such as keyword based systems), semantic intelligence applications focus on the meaning of the texts.
In 2008, the software company [[Collibra]] started commercializing years of academic research on semantic technology. It has positioned its [[Business semantics management]] approach as a way to achieve Semantic Intelligence.
[[Category:Business intelligence]]

{{Infobox Officeholder |name = Sergey Chemezov |image = Sergey Chemezov 2017.jpg |office = [[Rostec|CEO of Rostec Corporation]] |term_start = December 2007 |term_end = |predecessor = |successor = |birth_name = Sergey Viktorovich Chemezov |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1952|8|20|df=y}} |birth_place = [[Cheremkhovo, Irkutsk Oblast|Cheremkhovo]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] (now [[Russia]]) |death_date = |death_place = |spouse = Yekaterina Ignatova |children = 4 |party = |alma_mater = [[Military Academy of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Russia]]
[[Baykalsky State University of Economics and Law]] |profession = |signature = }} '''Sergey Viktorovich Chemezov''' ({{lang-ru|Серге́й Ви́кторович Чéмезов}}; born 20 August 1952) is the [[CEO]] of [[Rostec|Rostec Corporation]] (formerly the Director General of Rosoboronexport), chairman of the Union of Russian Mechanical Engineers, and a lieutenant-general. ==Biography== Chemezov was born on 20 August 1952 in the city of Cheremkhovo in [[Irkutsk Oblast]]. Chemezov graduated with honours from Irkutsk Institute of National Economy (presently Baikal State University of Economics and Law){{cite web|publisher=[[Rostec]]|accessdate=18 September 2013|url=http://www.rostec.ru/careers/university/1867|title=Baikal State University of Economics and Law|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131121075200/http://www.rostec.ru/careers/university/1867|archivedate=21 November 2013|deadurl=no|df=}} in 1975 and then completed his postgraduate education at the [[Military Academy of the General Staff of the Armed Forces of Russia]]. Chemezov has a doctorate in economics and is also a professor and full member of the Military Academy.{{cite web|url=http://www.rostec.ru/about/board/person/396|title=Sergey Viktorovich Chemezov|publisher=[[Rostec]]|accessdate=18 September 2013|deadurl=no|archivedate=13 August 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130813143848/http://www.rostec.ru/about/board/person/396|df=}} At the Irkutsk Scientific and Research Institute of Rare and Nonferrous Metals, Chemezov worked as an engineer, a research associate, and chief laboratory assistant. From 1980 to 1988, he worked at “Luch” Research-Industrial Association. From 1983 to 1988, Chemezov served as the head{{cite journal|journal=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|title=Sergey Viktorovich Chemezov|url=http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=27199601&ticker=AVAZP:RU|deadurl=no|archivedate=28 April 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140428154655/http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/people/person.asp?personId=27199601&ticker=AVAZP:RU|df=}} of the Luch Association representative office in [[East Germany]], where he met [[Vladimir Putin]] and [[Nikolay Tokarev]]. Nikolay Tokarev, Chemezov, and Vladimir Putin worked for their [[KGB]] boss [[Lazar Matveev]] while in East Germany and both Chermazov and Putin lived in the same block of flats in [[Dresden]].{{cite news | title = Putin visits his former KGB boss on his 90th birthday (VIDEO) | url = https://www.rt.com/viral/387578-putin-kgb-boss-birthday/ | work = RT | date = 8 May 2017 | access-date = 9 December 2017}} There they became friends.{{cite news|url=http://www.economist.com/node/9682621|title=The making of a neo-KGB state|publisher=[[The Economist]]|date=23 August 2007|accessdate=18 September 2013|place=[[Moscow]]|archivedate=9 October 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131009032052/http://www.economist.com/node/9682621|deadurl=no|df=}} From 1988 to 1996, Chemezov was deputy CEO of the “Sovintersport” Foreign Trade Association. From 1996 to 1999, he was chairman of the Department for Foreign Economic Relations within the Office for Presidential Affairs, serving under Vladimir Putin. Later he transitioned to the position of chairman of the Department for Foreign Economic Relations of the [[Presidential Administration of Russia]]. From September 1999 to November 2000, Chemezov served as CEO of Promexport. In August 2000, he became a member of the Presidential Committee on Military and Engineering Cooperation between Russia and Foreign Countries. From November 2000 to April 2004, Chemezov served as first deputy CEO of Rosoboronexport and then as its CEO from 2004 to 2007.{{cite news|author=Fred Weir|accessdate=18 September 2013|date=12 February 2007|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2007/0212/p04s01-woeu.html|title=Russia intensifies efforts to rebuild its military machine|publisher=[[The Christian Science Monitor]]|archivedate=28 October 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131028151522/http://www.csmonitor.com/2007/0212/p04s01-woeu.html|deadurl=no|df=}} By a decree of the Russian President, on 26 November 2007, Chemezov was named CEO of Russian Technologies Corporation,{{cite journal|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-19/russian-technologies-can-t-be-privatized-chemezov-update1-.html|author=Henry Meyer|title=Russian Technologies Can’t Be Privatized: Chemezov|journal=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]|date=19 November 2010|accessdate=18 September 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140428224228/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-19/russian-technologies-can-t-be-privatized-chemezov-update1-.html|archivedate=28 April 2014|deadurl=no|df=}} which was renamed Rostec in late 2012. At the 6th [[United Russia]] party convention held on 2 December 2006, Chemezov was elected to the party’s Supreme Council. At the 7th party convention on 26 May 2012, Chemezov was reelected. Chemezov coordinates United Russia’s “IT-Breakout” project, which since December 2010 has sought to discover and support outstanding young [[Information technology|IT]] innovators. On 28 April 2014, he was barred by the [[Presidency of Barack Obama|Obama administration]] from entering the United States.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/blogs/worldviews/wp/2014/04/28/u-s-announces-new-sanctions-on-russians-whos-on-the-list/|title=U.S. announces new sanctions on Russians: Who’s on the list|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]|author=Terri Rupar|date=28 April 2014|accessdate= 21 June 2014}} ==Offices== Chemezov has served as a member of the Board of Directors for: *[[United Aircraft Corporation|United Aircraft Corporation JSC]] (since 2006) *[[United Shipbuilding Corporation|United Shipbuilding Corporation JSC]] (since 2007) *[[Rusnano|Rusnano Corporation]] (since 2011) *[[Norilsk Nickel|MMC Norilsk Nickel]]{{cite journal|journal=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|date=11 March 2013|url=https://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20130311-702908.html|title=Rostec Head Chemezov To Join Norilsk Nickel Board -Report|accessdate=18 September 2013|archivedate=28 April *[[AvtoVAZ]]{{cite news|publisher=Automotive News Europe|date=29 June 2013|url=http://europe.autonews.com/article/20130629/ANE/130629883/ghosn-becomes-chairman-of-russian-carmaker-avtovaz|title=Ghosn *[[Rosoboronexport]] (since 2011; in August 2013 Chemezov was reelected for a third time) ==Academic activity, social activism and patronage== *Head of the Department of Military and Engineering Mechanical Engineers, a public organization (since April 2007) *President of the Russian Industrial Association of Employers in Mechanical Engineering (since April 2007) *Chairman of the Supervisory Board of Kalashikov Military and Sport Association, an interregional public organization (since April 2010) *Chairman of the Supervisory Board of the Foundation for the Support and Development of Board of Plekhanov Russian University of Economics *Chairman of the Supervisory Board of Gorchakov Public Diplomacy Foundation ==Family== Chemezov is married to Yekaterina Ignatova, who is a trained planning engineer. She is a co-founder and seventy percent stockholder of Kate LLC, a company that develops and manufactures automatic gearboxes. Ignatova is also the majority shareholder (along with Gor Nahapetyan, the managing director of [[Troika Dialog]]) of Étage, a chain of nineteen restaurants in Moscow. Chemezov has four children. According to information accessed in May 2009, Chemezov’s eldest son Stanislav (born in 1973) has been working for the company Itera. He is a thirty percent shareholder of Medfarmtekhologia, a member of the board of directors of AvtoVAZEnergo,{{cite news|url=http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1078952.html|title=Twelve Who Have Putin's Ear|publisher=[[Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty]]|agency=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|date=15 October 2007|accessdate=18 September 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131024184232/http://www.rferl.org/content/article/1078952.html|archivedate=24 October 2013|deadurl=no|df=}} and chairman of the board of directors of Interbusinessgroup, which holds via structural companies such commercial organizations as Independent Insurance Group LLC, Oborontsement JSC, and Oborontsement-energo LLC. Since 2003 Stanislav Chemezov has been the co-owner (together with Vladimir Artyakov’s son, Dmitri) of the Meridian hotel facilities in Gelendzhik. According to other information accessed in May 2009, Chemezov’s second son was studying in a medical institute. His youngest son was in primary school and his daughter was a graduate student at [[Moscow State Institute of International Relations|MGIMO University]]. ==Awards== *[[Order For Merit to the {{Unreferenced|date=February 2007}} {{Infobox video game |title = SimPark |image = SimPark Coverart.jpg |developer = [[Maxis]] |publisher = [[Maxis|Maxis Kids]] |designer = Roxana Wolosenko
Claire Curtin |programmer = Ed Nanale |artist = Bonnie Borucki
Sharon Barr |composer = [[Jerry Martin (composer)|Jerry Martin]] |engine = |series = ''[[List of Sim video games|Sim]]'' |released = [[1996 in video gaming|1996]] |genre = [[Simulation video game|Simulation]], [[Educational game|Education]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Microsoft Windows|Windows]], [[Windows 3.1x|Windows 3.x]], [[Mac OS]] }} '''''SimPark''''' is a 1996 [[video game]] by [[Maxis]]. The object of the game is to cultivate and manage a successful [[park]]. Similar to ''[[SimTown]]'', it is targeted more towards [[child]]ren than the average player. ''SimPark'' attempts to show the importance of [[ecology|ecological]] balance. It could well be considered a 'lite' version of ''[[SimIsle: Missions in the Rainforest|SimIsle]]''. == Gameplay == [[Image:Simpark.jpeg|thumb|left|''SimPark'' screenshot]] Players have to quickly learn how doing (or not doing) various things will affect how their park grows. For instance, if certain [[flower]] types aren't planted, the park won't attract [[bee]]s. If the bees aren't flying around the park, then [[pollination]] won't occur, which is an important aspect of keeping the park growing. On top of properly managing the [[plant]] and [[animal]] population, players are also required to identify the park's plants and animals. Players often receive in-game email, such as their boss telling them to make the park more diverse, or their virtual mother telling about life back at home (e.g.: "I baked you a cake..." etc.) Occasionally, the Boss's pet frog Rizzo will make an appearance on the screen to give the player advice, or nag about the way they're handling things. The park can experience disasters, including: *[[Waste|Garbage]] Dump: The Garbage Dump is just a big pile of rubbish. As soon as it is made, rats start to produce from it and inhabit your park. The only way to get rid of the garbage dump is to put water on it or place lots of garbage-eating animals such as rats and black bears, around the garbage dump. *[[Fire]] * [[Kudzu]] * [[Alien invasion]]: The Alien Invasion consists of flat, pink-and-blue creatures that litter the park grounds and sometimes float on the water. If the map is clicked to get a zoomed-out map view, the pattern the Aliens form may be in the shape of letters. One example of this is a message which reads: "Surrender, Dorothy". This is a parody of the movie ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]''. The only way to get rid of aliens, aside from using cheat codes, is to bulldoze them with the "[[Bulldozer]]" tool. The option of using a microphone feature allows you to click on park-goers and listen to what they have to say. Some of the more memorable quotes include, "My socks don't match," "I didn't brush my teeth this morning," "Eddie! Oh Eddie! Where are you?" and "My favourite book is ''Wind in the Willows." ==External links== *{{moby game|id=/simpark}} {{Sim series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Simpark}} [[Category:1996 video games]] [[Category:Maxis Sim games]] [[Category:Children's educational video games]] [[Category:Business simulation games]] [[Category:Mac OS games]] [[Category:Strategy video games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Video games developed in the United States]] [[Category:Video games with isometric graphics]] [[Category:Video games set in North America]]

{{Infobox person | name = Sylvia Mulinge | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = {{Birth year and age|1977}} | birth_place = [[Kenya]] | death_date = | death_place = | alma_mater ='''[[University of Nairobi]]'''
{{small|([[Bachelor of Science|BSc]] in [[Food science|Food Science & Technology]])}} | occupation = [[Corporate Executive]] | years_active = 2004 — present | nationality = Kenyan | ethnicity = | citizenship = Kenyan | residence = | known_for = Management | networth = | home_town = | title = Director of the Consumer Business Unit at [[Safaricom]] | spouse = | religion = }} [[File:Sylvia Mulinge..jpg|thumb|right|Sylvia Mulinge, Director of Special Projects at Safaricom]] '''Sylvia Wairimu Mulinge''' (née Sylvia Wairimu), is a [[Kenya]]n [[businesswoman]] and [[corporate executive]]. Since November 2018, she serves as the ''Chief Customer Officer'' at [[Safaricom]], reporting directly to the [[chief executive officer]] of the telecommunications company.{{cite web| url=https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/corporate/companies/Mulinge-gets-powerful-post-in-Safaricom-executives/4003102-4834472-da5cpq/index.html |title=Mulinge gets powerful post in Safaricom executives shake up |access-date=3 November 2018 |date=2 November 2018 |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |last=Alushula | first=Patrick |location=Nairobi}} Previously, from 1 October 2018 until 2 November 2018, she served as the Director, Special Projects at [[Safaricom]],{{cite web |access-date=27 September 2018 |date=27 September 2018 | first=Patrick |last=Alushula |title=Sylvia Mulinge returns to Safaricom as Dar job hits snag |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]]|url=https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/corporate/companies/Mulinge-returns-to-Safaricom-as-Dar-job-hits-snag-/4003102-4780424-11af3arz/index.html }}{{cite web| url=https://citizentv.co.ke/news/safaricom-takes-back-sylvia-mulinge-after-tanzania-blocks-appointment-213307/ |title=Sylvia Mulinge back at Safaricom after Tanzania blocks appointment |access-date=27 September 2018 |date=27 September 2018 | publisher=Citizens Television Kenya |first=Joseph |last=Bonyo | location=Nairobi}} Before that, she was the Director of the Consumer Business Unit at [[Safaricom]], the largest telecommunications company in Kenya.{{cite web|access-date=14 November 2017 | url=https://www.safaricom.co.ke/about/about-safaricom/who-we-are/senior-management |title=Safaricom: Sylvia Mulinge, Director Consumer Business Unit |date=14 November 2017 |author=Safaricom |publisher=[[Safaricom]] |location=Nairobi}} ==Background and education== She was born in Kenya and attended ''St. Xaviers Primary School'' (1983-1990) in the town of [[Nakuru]], and ''Mary Mount Secondary School'' (1991-1994) for her elementary and secondary education. She studied at the [[University of Nairobi]], graduating in 2000 with a [[Bachelor of Science]] degree in [[Food science|Food Science and Technology]].{{cite web| accessdate=14 November 2017 |date=14 November 2017 | url=https://www.linkedin.com/in/sylviamulinge/ |title=Mulinge Sylvia, Director for Consumer Business at Safaricom Limited |publisher=[[Linkedin]] |last=Mulinge |first=Sylvia}} ==Career== She began her career in August 2004, at [[Unilever]], the European consumer products [[conglomerate (business)| conglomerate]], working as the Assistant Regional Brand Manager in the laundry division, based in [[Durban]], [[South Africa]]. After nine months in South Africa, she was transferred to Kenya, as the brand manager for [[Sunlight (cleaning product)| Sunlight]], a Unilever brand. She worked there for another nine months, from May 2005 until January 2006, based in Nairobi. In February 2006 she was hired by Safaricom Limited as the manager responsible for the company's pre-pay product, working in that capacity until November 2007, when she was promoted to the rank of Head of Retail, in which position she served until August 2009. For the 21 months, from August 2009 until April 2011, she worked as the Head of Safaricom Business, responsible for sales. In May 2011, she was promoted to General Manager for Enterprise Business, working in that capacity for the next four years. In May 2015, she was promoted to the position of Director of Consumer Business at Safaricom. At Safaricom, she rose through the ranks to become a member of the senior management team at the company. ==Other considerations== In 2014, Sylvia Wairimu Mulinge was named among the "Top 40 Women Under 40 in Kenya 2014" by [[Business Daily Africa]], a daily business newspaper published by the [[Nation Media Group]].{{cite web| date=9 July 2014 |accessdate=14 November 2017 | url=http://calibratedblossom.blogspot.com/2014/07/top-40-women-under-40.html |title=Calibrated Blossom: Top 40 Women under 40 in Kenya 2014 |publisher=Calibrated Blossom Quoting [[Business Daily Africa]] |location=Nairobi|author=Calibrated Blossom}}{{cite web|url=http://docplayer.net/45377134-The-list-of-those-who-made-it-to-bd-s-annual-list-of-women-to-watch-friday-20th-june-2014-your-free-copy-the-business-of-taking-a-break.html | title=The list of those who made it to Business Daily's annual list of Women to Watch | date=20 June 2014 |author=DPN | accessdate=14 November 2017 |publisher=Docplayer.net (DPN) | location=Nairobi}} In April 2018, Sylvia Mulinge was named the [[chief executive officer]]-designate at [[Vodacom Tanzania]], replacing ''Ian Ferrao''. The position is based in [[Dar es Salaam]], [[Tanzania]]. The appointment was effective 1 June 2018.{{cite web|title=Safaricom’s Mulinge to head Tanzania Vodacom | url=https://www.businessdailyafrica.com/corporate/companies/Safaricom-s-Sylvia-Mulinge-appointed-Vodacom-Tanzania-CEO/4003102-4379302-gk4cqq/index.html |access-date=9 April 2018 |date=9 April 2018 |newspaper=[[Business Daily Africa]] |location=Nairobi | first=James |last=Ngunjiri}} ==See also== * [[Susan Oguya]] * [[Iddah Asin]] * [[Robert Collymore]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://nairobinews.nation.co.ke/news/safaricom-executive-charged-causing-pedestrians-death/ Safaricom Executive to be Charged With Causing Pedestrian's Death] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20170801021145/http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2016/04/15/safaricom-director-denies-she-fled-chase-bank-ownership-two-days_c1333131 Safaricom director denies she fled Chase Bank ownership two days before collapse] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mulinge, Sylvia}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1977 births]] [[Category:University of Nairobi alumni]] [[Category:Kenyan women in business]] [[Category:21st-century businesswomen]] [[Category:People from Nairobi]] [[Category:Kenyan business executives]] [[Category:Kenyan businesspeople]] [[Category:Kenyan women business executives]] [[Category:Chief executive officers]]

{{Refimprove|date=September 2010}} '''Test management tools''' are used to store information on how testing is to be done, plan testing activities and report the status of quality assurance activities. The tools have different approaches to testing and thus have different sets of features. Generally they are used to maintain and plan manual testing, run or gather execution data from automated tests, manage multiple environments and to enter information about found defects. Test management tools offer the prospect of streamlining the testing process and allow quick access to data analysis, collaborative tools and easy communication across multiple project teams. Many test management tools incorporate [[requirements management]] capabilities to streamline test case design from the requirements. Tracking of defects and project tasks are done within one application to further simplify the testing.
==Structuring the test process== Test management tools give teams the ability to consolidate and structure the test process using one test management tool, instead of installing multiple applications that are designed to manage only one step of the process. Test management tools allow teams to manage test case environments, automated tests, defects and project tasks. Some applications include advanced dashboards and detailed tracking of key metrics, allowing for easy tracking of progress and bug management.
==Implementation== A test management tool that includes everything needed to manage the test process can save testers the hassle of installing separate applications that are necessary for the testing process. They can be implemented with minimal programming ability, allowing for easy installation and monitoring of the test process across multiple project groups. Once installed, teams have instant access to a user interface and can immediately start running and recording test cases. These types of applications are designed to simplify the test management process with high levels of automation and tracking built in, yet don't require advanced programming skills or knowledge to implement. They are useful for teams who manage a variety of test cases and for larger teams who need an all-inclusive application for project management.
==Using== Once a project has kicked off, a test management tool tracks bug status, defects and projects tasks, and allows for collaboration across the team. When administering test cases, users can access a variety of dashboards to gain access to data instantly, making the test process efficient and accurate. The type of dashboard used is determined by the scope of the project and the information and data that needs to be extracted during the testing process. Data can be shared and accessed across multiple project teams, allowing for effective communication and collaboration throughout the testing process.
==See also== *[[Test management]] *[[Portal:Software testing]] *[[Software testing]] *[[Test automation management tools]]
